reviewText:
This one has a lot of promise.

It's a fairly traditional MTG-esque card game, but with some significant differences:

(1) turns are simultaneous;
(2) you pick three characters from your deck to be 'commanders' (whose abilities you can use even if they aren't in play);
(3) there are three zones of play - attack, defence, and support. Attackers can only hit the opponent's defence zone, and vice versa. The support zone protects characters from most harm.
(4) all movement between zones happens simultaneously with the other play - so you declarae attackers without knowing what the enemy will block with.

These elements adds a huge amount of prediction and bluffing into the mix. Do you rush in with your unstoppable walrus in the hopes that they don't add more defenders, or do you move him off the battlefield to dodge a possible death ray? Do you cast Stumble on a character, knowing that if they don't attack, the spell will fizzle?

Adding to that, players have both health *and* morale to worry about. Producing twenty cheap blockers may keep your fortress intact, but evey time one of your characters die, your team takes a hit to their morale - the more legendary the character, the bigger the hit. Some decks specialise on being so defensive that the opponent's attacks sap their own morale. Hit 0 morale, and you're out of the game, regardless of how much you're winning.

These core mechanics strike a fine balance between accessibility and depth. You won't need to spend half an hour reading all of the opponent's cards, but there's still much more going on in every situation than you'll ever find in something like Hearthstone.

There's great variety between the game's seven factions. One has discliplined samurai and patient monks. One has uzi-wielding angels. One has bears. Every card's art is actually a looping animation, and while each faction focuses on a few different mechanics, you can mix up to three factions at a time (foregoing some of the more dedicated members of each group).

So yeah, it has a lot going for it, especially for a 'free' game.
As for the cash shop...well, the singleplayer campaign gives you starter decks and additional cards for all factions, plus you get a free booster pack every time you gain a level. Points earned can be spent on drafts, which also have pretty great rewards.

Eventually, you may want to buy some new packs/decks, and they're all...not terribly priced. They're also not entirely essential, since legendary characters aren't necessarily 'better', they just add more options. All-up, this one is certainly worth a look.

reviewText:
Infinity Wars is a very good Trading Card Game, complete with animations for all the cards and a unique, sort of M:TG-light feel. It has a fully realized backstory, voice acting in the campaign, and some lovely art.

-Sound: 7/10 The sounds and music in the game are vibrant, although the music could do with some more variation. The obvious sound for a match being made is a great boon to those of us who alt-tab out during the interminable waiting times between matches.

-Gameplay: 4/10 The actual cardgame mechanics are well done, built to be quick, accessible, and with a surprising amount of depth. The tutorial explains things very well, and the game gives you several starter decks for completing the campaign mode. You're given more cards for winning many matches and leveling up. It should be a fun game! This is ruined by a terrible matchmaking process, pay-2-win kiddies, and ranked play being restricted until you have essentially put hundreds of hours into the game. At the time of this writing I am level 19, with something like three hundred matches against other players, with another two hundred or so against bots. I am not yet high enough to play in the ranked matches.

-Graphics: 5/5 Graphics, to me, have a lower impact on my total review score as I do not need ULTRA GRAFIKS to enjoy a videogame. Considering that it is a card game, though, Infinity Wars has lush graphics, with 3d effects for the battlefield and animations for all of the cards in the game. I almost wanted to keep collecting cards simply to see what the animations were for every card. They range the gamut from beautiful, to amusing, to even touching.

-Replayability: 2/10 This is a big sticking point with me. Normally, a card game like Infinity Wars would, theoretically, have a much higher replayability rating, but the matchmaking service is just, just awful. There's no level-tied matches and it is ENTIRELY possible and MORE THAN likely that your level 2 using a starter deck can, and will, face a level 50 player using only cards he spent real money on. I have also waited more than ten minutes for a match, and no one wants that.

-Cheese -5/-5  Cheese is a special rating for me. It's a sign of how much the game is, for me at least, ruined by the Cash Shop. There are some games, like Rust, where the Cash Shop is only for cosmetic items. This game is completely broken by the cash shop. For about 20 USD, you have enough of their premium currency (Did I mention the premium currency? No? Well it's there. BIG TIME) to afford several store decks and booster packs. It completely wrecks the balance.

Total Score: 13/30 I cannot recommend this game. Although there is fun to be had, and I really do enjoy the gameplay, the overwhelming presence of the cash shop, horrible matchmaking, premium currency, and lack of any coherent system for tiered matches ruin it. Do not pick up this game, unless you can stomach either playing against bots, spending real money on digital cards for a 'free' game, or being beaten constantly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game since fairy early in the closed beta, and even then it continued to challenge and entertain as a superb strategy tcg.  A few points (some large, some small) that seperate Infinity Wars from other major TCGs such as Magic and Hearthstone:

1) Both players take their turns simultainiously, once both players have locked in their actions for the turn (you cannot see what your opponent decides to do until the turn happens) everything unfolds at the same time, making for fun and balanced (no 1st or 2nd turn advantage to exploit) game pacing.

2) The 3 combat zones, and command zone (4 zones total) in which cards can be moved around make for great strategy.  You must utilize the zones to your advantage, as well as bluff and use mind games to keep your opponents on their toes.  Your opponent might be pulling their hair out because of your use in manuevering your troops between the support and attack zones, leaving them unable to be dealt with.

3) All the artwork on the cards is animated!  This might seem like a superficial point, and well it is, but it's something that Magic is unable to do, and Hearthstone only does on their 'golden' cards.  In Infinity Wars all cards have artwork that has some level of animation to it, giving them a little more personality and depth.

4) It's still in beta!  There's still so much more in the works that it's amazing.  Even as is the game is a blast to play, yet in the future the game will only bloom and become even more robust and smooth in both gameplay and functionality of the UI.

5) It's FREE!  Much like Hearthstone, this game can be played with zero dollars of investment.  Through minimal daily effort it's possible to ammass a collection capable of building a fairly competitive deck, or at least enough points to start doing drafts (Rift Runs) on a regular basis.

6) Terror Moose!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic game. A must try for everyone.

Edit June 2015 : After I don't know how long in development, the cards are exactly the same. There is no new content and everything has stagnated since I first tried it in alpha. It has good potential but it's stuck in the early stages.

PROS
1. A simultaneous action system where players play their cards and actions at the SAME time.

2. Morale system is interesting.
It provides another way to poke at an enemy, although Deal One Damage (DOD)" to a life pool would be just as effective. Currently
date: only designed for defensive play.\n\n3. Command
hoursPlayed: Assault
voteText:
Defense zones provide variety of play.
Command provides a camander zone that cannot be directly attacked. It is similar to the Heroes in other Trading Card Games. The only difference being commanders being expendable in this game.
Support provides an area for troops to get buffed/choose the right timing to appear. This is a fantastic idea as it improves the efficiency of resource spending e.g. summon a pair of 3 costs creatures one turn after another but bringing them to the battlefield on the same turn together.
Defense and Assault zones help with tactical movement. Unit order affects how efficiently you use your tropps. You can even swap troops between zones. Even simple actions such as choosing who goes first is important.

Trading system is fantastic. As compared to other online TCG games which do not provide a trading system to maximize profit e.g. MMDOC
helpfulPercent:
Hearthstone. This is a great boon to players who play Infinity Wars. +++


CONS

reviewText:
I’ve played a couple of digital card games extensively (Shadow Era, Hearthstone) as well as dabbled with a few others (Solforge, PoxNora, Kingdoms CCG).  Out of all of these digital card games, I would say that I have only truly loved Shadow Era’s gameplay mechanics, so when I read about Infinity Wars on Steam, I was hesitant, as history demonstrated that I was inclined to dislike a TCG more often than not. Furthermore, after I downloaded Infinity Wars and jumped into the tutorial, I felt even more hesitant, because I found its simultaneous-turn system and multi-zone battlefield confusing to learn.

I cannot stress enough how glad I am to have fumbled through the tutorial and AI campaign missions. As a result, I discovered a true strategic gem – a gem in beta with much more polish than many other digital card games which have been fully released. Sure, Infinity Wars has gorgeous animated cards, a delightful music score, and engrossing atmosphere/lore with 8 distinctly different factions [8, not including the Star Trek factions]. That’s super. But what sells me are the game mechanics. Unlike most other digital card games, the battlefield of Infinity Wars is divided into multiple zones (command zone, support zone, assault zone and defense zone). You can move your characters between most of these zones, and certain destructive spells only work on your opponent’s characters when they are in certain zones at a certain moment in time.  In addition, turns are taken simultaneously, which results in plenty of wicked mind-games going on between you and your opponent in PVP. It sounds a bit complicated, but trust me -- it’s awesome.

In other digital card games, I sometimes felt frustrated at not being able to draw a major card in time (major = integral part of my deck strategy), or felt the frustrations of pay2win and lack of balance. Infinity Wars addresses the first concern with the command zone mechanic (3 “commander” characters, or characters which are integral to a deck’s strategy, are available at the start of the game, and you can play them on the actual battlefield or use their abilities as soon as you have the resource [mana] for them). Furthermore, my frustrations of getting a “bad draw” are mostly quelled by the trading post system, in which a player can obtain extra cards, or swap out cards, by paying resources. I don’t feel that Infinity Wars follows a pay2win business model at all – you can actually build a competitive deck fairly quickly. You receive a large selection of cards by completing the academy (training) and campaign missions, and earn cards by playing each day and completing achievements. Very rarely have I seen a card played by an opponent in PVP that screamed “IWIN” (you know what I mean). In other words, I think the game is pretty well-balanced for a beta. There are favorable and not-so-favorable matchups depending on which faction(s) you utilize, of course.

I think that strategic-minded gamers will also love deck-building in Infinity Wars, as you can combine cards from different factions to create a truly unique deck that’s perfectly suited to one’s individual play-style. Furthermore, I love that there are many different ways to win, aside from the standard “destroy the opponent’s base”. Certain factions lean towards playing a certain way to win, and mixing complementary cards belonging to different factions in order to reach such a win condition is incredibly fun. As soon as I discovered there was a super-defensive faction that was based on Ancient Chinese lore and obtaining board-control in long, drawn-out games, I was like, “OH HELL YES, THEY TOTALLY MADE THAT FACTION WITH MY INTERESTS AND PLAYSTYLE IN MIND!” (I’m referring to Descendants of the Dragons). I splashed my Descendants deck with some complementary healing and buff cards from a different faction (Warpath), and soon enough, rainbows were shooting out of my nostrils (that’s a good thing).

I do want to make a comparison to another digital card game before I conclude. However, I don't want to ramble about Hearthstone too much.  I want this review to mostly focus on the intrinsic qualities of Infinity Wars, but I have to stress how multi-dimensional and in-depth Infinity Wars is compared to Hearthstone. The complex bluffing games essential to Infinity Wars, multi-zone battlefields, as well as the creative freedom of its deck-building system, just makes Hearthstone seem so one-dimensional in comparison. In other words, Infinity Wars truly feels like a battlefield, with 3 commanders accessible from the get-go which complement one’s unique play-style and desired win condition. As long as it is financially feasible, I hope that Lightmare, the developers of Infinity Wars, will continue to develop their game with the more strategically-minded" niche gamer in mind
date: as opposed to making “catering for the casual masses” their number one priority.\n\nOf course
recommended: Infinity Wars has its flaws. I encounter numerous display bugs each day
hoursPlayed: and I think the user interface needs much refinement (why can’t I sort my cards so I can easily differentiate between my soul-bound and tradable cards?). That said
voteText: I strongly feel as though Lightmare are on the right track. From what I’ve seen
helpfulPercent: they’re a cool company that truly listens to community feedback (you’ll see them actively participating in discussions with the community
votesHelpful: even outside of the official forums and Steam).\n\nIf this gigantic rant makes one reader (who is interested in strategy and/or digital card games) think "Hey
votesTotal: Infinity Wars appears rather complicated at first
votesFunny: but I would like to approach it with an open-mind and check out the game mechanics!" -- I would be very happy."

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nIn a world where games such as Hearthstone and Magic: The Gathering are gaining publicity, it's nice to take a look at one of the lesser known games. Infinity Wars, in my opinion, is a phenomenal game. The strategy needed to play well, the aesthetics of the playing field and cards, and the overall flow of the game just feel natural to me. I will admit, it was somewhat difficult to understand at first, but that's somewhat understandable. However, after playing with the game a bit, crafting a deck, and playing around in the different modes, I was hooked. One of the most important things to do if you want to learn how to play this game well is to do the puzzles that the game has provided. Not only can they provide you with prizes after beating them, but they also give you tips and tricks as to more advanced plays that you can incorporate into your own play style. If I could make one criticism, it's that it is somewhat difficult to accumulate in-game currency to purchase card pack or decks, especially since the developers rarely, if ever, give out premium currency for free. However, at this point, I'm just nitpicking. So, to conclude, this game is great once you understand it, and I hope that whoever's reading this will pick up the game and have an infinitely good time.

I just happened to stubble across it while looking for free-to-play titles, but I'm glad I found it. Its a fairly interesting game with a zone-based playing field--which I found to be very odd for my first launchings of the game, but just goes along with the inital foreign feel. Considering that perticular mechanic, it doesn't feel like an extra or poorly thought out part of the game. Actually rather helpful, especially in later devised strategies.

I went straight to the campaign. Tutorials? They exist, and are actually interesting, but I went right to the campaign. Honestly, it didn't matter all that much which one I went into first. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing this game since the summer of 2013.

Things that sold me:

- Pauper & Merge Deck Mode - Where player skill and luck of the draw is the factor rather than best collection of cards
- All cards can be collected, nothing exclusive
- Unique gameplay mechanics which can only be done in the digital space
- You can buy booster packs, but as with Faeria, they are going for vanity item model
- Morale mechanic which hedges against stalemates seen in other TCGs
- A little bias here, but one of the best community managers is at the helm of this game that puts AAA guys to shame

Out of all the physical and digital TCGs, this is by far my favorite. The lore is amazing, very thematic, the gameplay mechanics and strategy is something I've been craving for. It's kinda like picking up FTL for the first time. You never knew you had a niche to fill until you played it. All this coupled with a community manager that appears to get no sleep because he seems to be everywhere willing to answer questions. Out of all dTCGs, they are the underdogs/sleepers and I'm rooting for them.

Tips:


Play through the campaign because you get a ton of cards and when you're done you should make a good determination what deck you start out with. Make it a good choice depending on your play style, because you usually get a super rare card for the initial superbooster pack/deck. Play a few merge deck matches so you can get a grasp of what other cards do and build up your xp/card collection. You can literally get by with your starting cards and mass a huge collection just by playing matches, heck they give you cards just by logging on everyday. Some of the top players have put in little into purchases other than vanity items to support the devs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I. Am. Hooked.

Yes, it's neat that the cards are animated I guess, but not a big deal. The mechanics of the game, however, are a big deal; and are an incredibly unique take on TCG. (Yes, TCG - you can trade!)

The biggest things that caught my eye:

'Command cards' - three unit cards that you pre-select when making the deck that start off in the corner, revealed. You can tailor specific opening strategies around this, and there are tons of possibilities here. And you don't get screwed over by bad draws, because they're always there at the start.

'Trade post' - Speaking of bad draws, the 'trade post' function not only allows you the usual 'mulligan' at the start of the game, but also gives you the ability to spend otherwise unused resources on drawing new cards or even swapping out cards you don't need to draw new cards (for less resources). This is an AWESOME mechanic for bypassing those games where you're basically twiddling your thumbs as you draw useless land cards in magic.

It's actually F2P. You get a lot of usable cards from playing through the campaign, and you accrue a decent amount of generic in-game currency to purchase booster/blister packs easily. After a single day of playing I was able to afford a couple of blister packs and I was quite happy with that. One could probably afford a booster pack maybe once a week? Depends on how much you play of course.

You can trade. (Well, aside from the starter cards you unlock in campaign mode at least.) I had given up hope that a card game would EVER let you trade, after all the CCGs I've played.

There's much more I'm forgetting, and there wouldn't be enough space anyway.

TL;DR: It's free, it's actually got a good F2P model from what I can tell, and it's worth your time. Get it.

reviewText:
After wasting crap load of time and money on MTG, I decided to return to TCG once Digital TCG started rising again (i.e. Hearthstone).  Hearthstone didn't do it for me because it was one of the most casual ♥♥♥♥ I've ever tried in my life.  So I looked for a better alternative.  Then I found Infinity Wars.  I'll cover IW in two main aspects: F2P and Gameplay/Strategy potentials.

Is it F2P?
I think the game is pretty fair.  Firstly, yes you can actually TRADE cards in this game.  You can buy Lightmare Points to buy booster packs but you can also earn IW Points to buy booster packs.  You earn IW points from playing games online, including private games with your friends.  How many games does it take to buy a booster pack?  I think it is around 30-40 games (Just a rough estimate, haven't done the math myself), assuming 50% win rate.  But there's more.

When you start the game, you will have to play some campaigns.  They will teach you about each factions and you will earn starter deck of each faction when you complete first 3 or 4 missions of each factions.  Also, any games you play, you get experience points for your account and you will get a free booster pack every time you level up.  Every level requires more experience than the last but in the beginning you will level up often and you will be showered with booster packs.  But there's more.

There is a thing called daily rewards and weekly quests.  Every week, you will be given 3 quests.  It can be just gaining certain amount of experience or playing some amount of PvP.  You get one random card for each quest you complete.  You will get 1 random card for logging in daily and you will get another random card for playing 3 PvP games.  So assuming you are diligent, you get 2 cards per day, another 2*7+3 = 17 cards per week.  And these are truly RANDOM cards.  I've gotten couple of legendaries just from logging in every day.   It's pretty rare but it's really nice when you get them.

I also need to note that free cards you get from daily, weekly or levels are SOULBOUND, meaning you can't trade them.  Only the cards you get with Lightmare or IW points are tradeable.  I think it's fair considering how many cards they pump into you and you don't want to screw the trade economy.

So in summary,
1. 2 cards every day (untradeable)
2. 3 cards every week (untradeable)
3. 1 booster pack (15 cards) every level (untradeable)
4. In-game points you earn to buy booster packs (tradeable)

Gameplay/Strategy
IW is definitely unique.  I'll cover them in sections.

1. Simultaneous turns
Most card games are turn-based but this game has SIMULTANEOUS turns, meaning you and your opponent plan at the same time and things happen all at once.  This means you have to plan according and predict your opponent's moves instead of waiting for them to make a move and react.  If you played MTG, then you know about saving that kill spell in case your opponent buffs a creature into a raging hulk or saving that counter-spell in case he casts some devastating spell.  Not in this game.  You have to predict them coming.  On the other way around, you can dodge certain spells by moving your characters in and out of the battlefield.  This adds an element of mind-game.  Instead of casting spells and hope that your opponent doesn't have an answer for it, you can move around it, dodging, baiting and calling shots.  It really depends on the deck but some games can be very intense.  You don't just play your strategy and hope your opponent doesn't have an answer to it.  If you know they could potentially counter you, you can find a way around by baiting.  This is only possible in Digital TCG so it's taking full advantage of the digitalized TCG!  This fact alone is worth checking this game out.

2. Deck building
Alright, magic has 5 colored factions but IW has 8?  (There's 2 more factions for Star Trek series but I won't cover that here)  And you can only have up to 3 factions for each deck?  What's up with that?  Well, IW is different in a sense that your deck will be based on 3 cards and they are called Commanders.  Every deck has 3 commanders and their faction alliance determines how you build the deck and each faction has their unique strategy and combining them.  You can build a pure faction deck and play to its fullest strength or you can make a deck of hybrid factions, playing with jack-of-all-trade playstyle.  You aren't just limited to 3 factions because there is a card that allows you to play any factions.  ANY character card can be a commander.  The 3 commanders are placed in the commander zone at every game and you can play them whenever you want, provided that you have enough resources.  Most of the time, you can play the character's ability from the commander zone so you can even build a deck around that entire aspect.

If you played MTG, you know well about resource management.  In IW, you gain 1 resource every turn so you rarely have to worry about being mana-screwed.  The commanders are like lands in a sense that they determine the color of your deck.  There are characters and spells to boost your resource to get ahead early so there are some resource management in the game.  Your deck should be consistent with your intended gameplay every time since you won't get mana-skrewed very well, provided that you balanced the resource curve.  Consistency is the key because I really hated getting mana screwed in MTG.  Honestly I think that is one of the major design flaws of MTG.  MTG is more flexible with deck building in a sense that you can have any color and any cards in your deck provided that you have the lands to support it.  But ultimately you have to buy those 20 dollar rare lands to even make your dreams possible.  I miss the potentials in MTG but not that much.  Coming from MTG which has beautifully balanced 5 color scheme (each color allies with 2 while opposing one), I felt kinda iffy about the whole factions thing, especially since the devs seem to intend to add or subtract them in the future (super not sure about this but there were 7 factions in the beginning but now there's 8. 10 if you include the non-canon ones) but I learned to love the lore and each faction is quite fun to try.

In summary:
1. Simulatneous turns for mind-games
2. Commanders and 8 unique factions for intersting deck building strategies
3. Basic resource management so you won't get mana screwed most of the time

reviewText:
pros: free-to-play, good tutorial (I recommend doing before you go to the campaign), hyped soundtrack, creatively animated card illustrations, animated UI & interface, windowed fullscreen option available, a lot of cards (all animated) with a ton of single player campaign missions & challenges (which rewards you with moar cards!1!!), you can construct as many custom decks (for free) as your heart desires with at least 9 different factions to choose from (but limited to 3 different factions per deck for it to be legal in multiplayer), gameplay allows two win conditions (reduce opponent health or morale to zero), gameplay allow ways to bluff & position. Also on the bottom right of the UI is an auction button (allows card draw & resource schemes) & at the bottom left is the undo button.

cons: the game requires you to create a login profile (why not just auto link with the steam account?), player vs player multiplayer modes has to be unlocked by completing single player challenges & leveling up your profile first (you need to be at least lvl 10 to play ranked constructed, although it's understandable due to experienced ranked opponents), few missing sound ques, the AI sometimes doesn't make the smartest decisions (& some campaign levels are trial&error), storyline is forgettable, when you close the chatbox during a multiplayer match there is no way of getting it back (& no way of reestablishing contact with previous opponents), ive experienced a few deck loading bugs

Overall, after playing for almost 2 decades of Magic: The Gathering & many other card games, Infinity Wars is by far the most compelling of all card games ive played. This is a must play for MTG, Hearthstone, Yu-gi-oh, etc. players - who long for a better card game that offers depth, easy to learn, customizable, streamlined online multiplayer ; but leaves out the pay-to-win BS, terrible UI & menu interfaces, & frustrating/inconvenient multiplayer experience.

Infinity Wars has my highest recommendation and a must play!
One of the most fun CCG experience out there.

reviewText:
First impression of beta; This TCG is made of some serious f**king win.

1. Unique and robust combat system combined with a very fluid interface.   The cards are beautifully animated when you inspect them and it is greatly appreciated.

2. Solid sound effects for a DTCG, which is sadly rare. It could be better and I'm sure it will, these devs look like they pump out a lot of content and patches.

3.Techo-fantasy setting.. It's cyber-punk on crack; Robots, demon-infused robots, robot's molesting demons, undead trying to eat the humans who are watching demons getting molested ... it's all here and its fresh and interesting genre for TCGs that is highly reminiscent of Warhammer 40K (which is definitely not a downside)

4. ANDROID SUPPORT. And iOS if you fancy burning money I guess.  But the options are all there and this is a huge drawcard.  I know a lot of people like myself prefer to play on tablets or phone, or at least have the option to.

5. It's F2P so f**king download and try it already, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
I've played very little, but I really liked it. It has its own niche of a playstyle, quite similar to Yu-gi-Oh (a game which I absolutely adore).

This game has a lot of potential and I love the way the game itself plays out. Granted I have my disagreements with some of the gameplay elements, but you can't love it all. It certainly doesn't break my Hearth like Cardstone does though. It doesn't try to kick me when I lose by also giving me nothing from card packs. That's of course after Cardstone opened a fresh wound with RNG and poured salt in it. Enough of Hearthstone though.

With a heavy heart I must say that I sadly can't recommend it to almost anyone I know. The artstyle is good, I love the design, but the battlefield, the animations and the soundeffects are sub-par AT BEST. They're simply horrible. Calling them stock would be doing them too much justice. There are top notch free sound effects available out there and this game doesn't seem to be using any. Either that or my game is just broken. It really erodes away the sheer gameplay potential of the game as its feel is so dull I can't force myself to launch it.

Once the animations and more importantly sound effects are fixed, the game will be MUCH less annoying. Right now it just has a complete lack of visual and audial charm.

I know it's hard designing quality animations and fitting proper sound effects, different ones for each card, also making the game much bigger in the process, but if it's done in the future, I'll change my view to a Recommend.

reviewText: Being a general fan of TCGs, I've played quite a few of them. Currently, I don't think there's a better TCG on the market than Infinity Wars. I'll just make a few comparisons with the ones I've been playing in the last few months.\n\nHearthstone is a finely polished TCG and as far as graphics goes, it's my top TCG. However, you have a fairly limited amount of cards and getting new ones is a chore. I can't honestly say it's pay-to-win, but it definitely pushes you into buying stuff because of the slow pace with which you get new cards. A real campaign does not exist, but you can buy a couple of missions for a steep price and finish it in a day (if you're slow). What pushed me over the edge and away from this game was the lack of rewards - when I beat challenges on nightmare difficulty and was simply returned to the main menu. It was at that moment that I said awwwww
date: forget it".\n\nHex is advertised as a revolutionary take on the TCG genre and it promises a lot. Promises is the key word here since there is almost no PvE content. Also
recommended: Hex still feels like just another MTG clone but with a god complex. In time
hoursPlayed: it might show itself as THE TCG game
voteText: but gamers (and everyone else
helpfulPercent: for that matter) don't particularly like waiting long for promises to come true.\n\nFinally

votesTotal:
cons and neutrals.

PROS
+ playing board elements differ from the standard MTG&clones layout
+ simultaneous turns make it less likely for you to wait for a slow opponent
+ every card is animated
+ a lot of achievements
+ cards

commentsCount: playing 3 games in a day
column16: finishing campaign missions

DId I mention that you get a whole deck of cards (40) for finishing the first 5 missions of a campaign?\n+ every non-cosmetic item (and some cosmetic ones as well) can be bought with the currency you earn from playing games\n+ you have additional options to utilize if you don't want to spend your energy on cards (shuffle and draw a card
column19: draw a card

increase max resources)

CONS

NEUTRALS

reviewText: I play a lot of CCG's in rl i used to play magic, spellfire, UFS(scout), world of warcraft, L5r, and many online electronic ccg's. I can say for sure infinity wars brings something unique to the table not knowing for either side who will be attacking or defending untill after you've made your moves and plays ads an incredible strategic depth to it. abilities more or less not resolving on an instant chain" really i think leads to a more healthy game environment(like l5r) than the judge heavy play of magic or similar games. i will say that the strategies that are truly viable in each symbol of infinity wars are unfortunately fairly limited for now .... but it really hasnt had that many booster sets yet give it time and i think each set will add new victory conditions and play styles.\n\nAs to the free to play  / pay to win. I can firmly say as a free player i have never felt like i couldnt compete even right after i finished the tutorial for all factions you get a lot of cards to work with and it doesnt take long to build at least 1 competitive deck
date: I like where they are going with thier model you can get more cards faster for money
recommended: you can but aestetic upgrades for money
hoursPlayed: they could probably use some in game currency booster options for real money. but on the whole you can indeed play this game 100% for free and have just as much chance to get rares and build a great deck you just wont get packs as fast as someone dropping real coin on it.  The aestetic upgrades are things like backgrounds for your decks while you play
voteText: and deck backings. i could maybe see them marketing custom special animations or special animated art for the cards as well ... almost like a "skin" if you will.\n\nLastly deck building is honestly a pleasure as you pick your commanders it automatically filters the cards out to match the "purity" of your deck so you dont have to sift through a mountain of cards and/or accidentily put an illegal card in it. theres a format checker so you can check to see if your deck is legal in a given format. as well as a built in cost breakdown for your deck so you can watch your curve
helpfulPercent:
a abilities/creatures/artifacts/locations split that not only tells you how many of each you have in deck but splits them up in the deck building screen so if you need to make an alteration things are fast and easy to find.

Theres all my pros now to the cons.

the game is young ... you will run across some things that young ccg's have such as cards that dont work 100% as printed(sleeper hakeem) and cards that are too strong in given meta like the location for dod that cant be targetted and wins them the game in short order
votesHelpful: there are precious few cards to counter it since its a location that cant be targetted so its "too dependable" a strategy there is not a full meta yet so combo decks tend to be king especially if they revolve around non creatures to win.  there is definitely rush mechanics(combo) with flame dawn
votesTotal: but control isnt quite there yet as a meta strategy and is almost exclusive to the dod for viability. reanimator works
votesFunny: but the games real problem is that aggro doesn't work
commentsCount: the threat that one could play an aggro deck keeps the more rediculious combo decks out of cycle in most ccg's
column16: sure killing things on the board works but ONLY in the context of going for a quick combo damage victory and scrapping the few early cards in your way(verore/flamedawn). aggro can't target enough things by default to be a viable deck strategy theres no "combobreaker" style play yet that works in competitive
column17: its just too hard to get to support row and command center and in the exiles case your hand. They also have situations where most of the colors dont specifically play well with others and 1 or 2 play really well. beasts only really target friendly"beast" cards
column18: but the robot faction seems to be able to pump anything under the sun
column19: verore and exiles seem the same way it seems silly why anyone would choose the second in either pairing over the other because they then have to bridge the hurdle of ..... "my cards dont help each other in 99% of cases how do i make this a cohesive deck strategy" while the first pair are so cohesive with anything they could just throw about anything in there on sybol or in neutral symbol and make it work somehow. I wish they would hire me as a card / rules designer i think i could do a lot for them mechanically.\n\nall things summed i would give it a 8/10 very stable game if you're tired of how rediculious the rules are in magic and you dont like stack based games prefer a more strategic feel like l5r as opposed to a solotaire combo vs possible combobreaker style of play like magic. you will like this game. if what you want is to spam 10 cards in a row that your opponent can't do anything about because he didn't specifically sidedeck against you and then proclaim you win. this is probably not the game for you."

reviewText:
Although I'm recommending this game, it's not without reserve.

I think it's a great take on the video game TCG genre. The battlefield concept is interesting and adds a lot of depth to the strategy and tactics of these games.

But I feel like the game doesn't give you enough alternatives to earn in-game cash to buy cards. I'm also not happy with the game's matching ability. As a starting player without even a PVP badge on my first PVP games, it kept matching me with someone that had gold badges on everything and kicked my butt thoroughly every single game. After my third match in a row with this guy I gave up playing for a while, and soured my first experience with PVP in the game.

Secondly, even though I've completed all the available single-player content, i don't feel like I have enough cards to field a viable deck in PVP unless I'm in pauper mode. So if you don't mind playing in pauper mode (and can find opponents in this mode), or if you want to spend the cash on one of the pre-made decks, you may be frustrated during your initial play against real players with full decks.

reviewText:
I've played many TCG games, ranging from Magic the Gathering, to Yu-Gi-Oh, to Hearthstone and so forth. In my honest opinion, Infinity Wars is pretty unique considering how hard it is to make a TCG game that seems fun and not as dull or repetitive as other games.
INNOVATIONS: Simultaneous turns
Unique effects that range from invincibility to ground units, to attacking if destroyed another character, etc.
Unique character abilities that range from a LARGE variety of things
A 4 Zone field which are Attack, Defense, Support and Command.
ALL cards are animated
Artifacts and Locations that allow a deck built around them
9 different factions, and more added as time goes on
The command section which allows expensive cards abilities to be used without putting them on the field
As you may see, it doesn't seem much. That's because it's too hard to write down without boring you with an extremely long list of excessive text which you or may not even read. But moving on, what you're actually looking for
PROS:A very good Free To Play model and is by no means a Pay to Win game
An infinite number of builds can be created due to the large variety of cards
A well balanced game compared to other TCG for not letting different factions have too much power over the other
This is not a brain dead game. An example of one would be, but not limited to Rush Down Hunter from Hearthstone
The staff is actually very responsive to the community and constantly listens to any suggestions

CONS:The layout of the game may confuse new players
The game looks pretty complex to new players
Hard to start getting into without playing at least 1 complete story line for Campaign for cards
Bots are in this game (the bad ones that exploits game mechanics), but the admins will be removing them
Have to wait 6 minutes for a person AFK in a game before kicking them and giving you a win
Have to wait 3 minutes if a person DCs before able to claim a win

CONCLUSION: Overall, I would say this is a well made TCG which gives a more military like spin to TCG as well as giving off a strategic mindset with all the new abilities, artifacts, locations, and effects, the only problems would be new players trying to get in to the game, and the AFK/DC system. The rest of the problems were made by part of the community that create bots to exploit the game to get rare cards.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm really liking Infinity Wars.  Normally, I would avoid games that have aspects of 'drain-your-wallet-to-get-the-cool-stuff' but I'm happy to report that after only 5 hours of playing, I have a few epic cards, and I'm really enjoying myself.

Gameplay, for the veteran MTG player, will feel very familar.  I like the layout, which is animated all pretty-like.  The cards themselves have great artwork, and it's not that hard at all to get a hang of the rules.

There's a few glitches or maybe issues that I'm not quite understanding -- when I play a location, the playfield seems to change to .. just a field.  The fortress disappears, etc.  Maybe that's cause I'm playing a nature/green/whatever factioned card?  Anyway ..

Deck construction is cool, but the instructional video shows a completely different layout (a more useful one) than what I got.  It's a bit of a pain to have to scroll through cards instead of being able to sort them by cost, abilities, faction, etc.  I'll have to look more into that, I'm probably just missing something.

Overall gameplay is quick and fun.  The AI for the campaigns is challenging, but I'm really looking forward to some PvP duels.

Highly recommend this free game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll readily admit, when I first saw the game in the Free to Play lists, I thought it was going to be a remade version of my favorite 3D card game, Duelists of the Roses.

What I got was something probably as good.

The card system in this game is easy to understand, but a challenge to master, the mark of a well designed, well thought out game.  You could probably spend hours if not days just planning out an ideal deck for whatever adversary pokes it's nose around the corner.  Even if you don't, there's plenty of starter decks, booster packs, and individual cards you'll earn over the course of your Infinity Wars career that will keep you coming back for more.  I like the unique card system, and the way you've built it the system would probably work for nothing else but this game.

Graphics are rather intriguing too, with only a handful of effects but hundreds of animated pictures for your cards, not including all the flavor text.  Everything is designed well, looks great, and best of all, makes you wonder what sort of crazy new animation lies on the next new card.  However, some of the animations I must say seem a bit...short...or bland, to the point they almost don't need to be animated in the first place.  And adding in a few alternative effects would help, like different ways for the fortress to be destroyed depending on the severity of your win, how you won,  and so on.

I'll score this game out of 20 for graphics and out of 30 for gameplay for a total of out of 50.

Graphics get 16 out of 20 for the aforementioned cards that really don't seem animated.  Try working on those and the score will definitely improve.

Gameplay will get the following scores:

Controls: 10 of 10.  Really well designed card control system, which allows you to choose to either play the card immediately or look at its information before playing.  In addition to this, allowing you to see the new cards played is always welcome to help you strategize better, and keeping both people blind until they hit the End Turn button is a very good decision, very sensible.  The commander concept also adds in a rather clever twist.

Competition: 8 of 10.  I cannot rate multiplayer simply because there is no way to account for every player in the game.  I can however account for the Campaign mode.  Which is very good.  Campaigns slowly progress in difficulty, actually a little too slowly for my tastes.  I'd like a little more challenge before I hit mission 20 or so please.  Other than that keep it up here.

Consequence: 10 of 10.  I cannot praise the card system enough in this game.  You will definitely be rewarded for returning and grasping a further understanding of your cards and how they work in conjunction with each other.  Learning which commanders you need for your deck and getting cards every time you get victories, level up, or do something noteworthy is a definite plus, which will keep you coming.  There aren't any real punishment as far as I've seen, which to me is good for a card game like this, since it's not meant to be a hardcore experience.  Outstanding.

All in all this game gets 44 of 50.  And that's a score I'll raise a glass to.  Glory for the Flame Dawn!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nInfinity Wars. Don't just pass it up because it's a free to play card game. It really is free to play! There is premium cash you can buy, but all the things you can buy with premium cash you can also buy with the regular in game money! So you don't have to pay real money for anything! The games graphics and card animations are amazingly detailed and the game is SUPER easy to get the hang of. There's a campaign mode as well on online, so you can always customize your deck to be the absolute best ever and show all of your friends who's the REAL boss! The game doesn't take much to run and for being in it's Beta stage, it's got a WHOOOOLE LOT of stuff to do in it already! Every stage you complete in the campaign earns you more cards, and sometimes booster packs with rare cards! If you like strategy games or card game, then Infinity Wars is definitely for you!

reviewText:
What if I told you there was a game that was a animated cardgame with MTG and hearthstone like gameplay? Well, this is it. Infinity Wars is definitely for those who want to play single player or compeditive multiplayer against others.  With plenty different races and linear story missions similar to the MTG game you'll find as much replayability as a card game has. But it's uniques way of attacking/blocking sets it's self appart from other cardgames like MTG. By yourself against CPU's or against friends you can spend time having an awesome adventure!

Pros:
Decient SinglePlayer Experience
Free Drafting
FREE!!
Nice looking card art and every card is animated which looks pretty cool!
Unique attack and defend zones set it appart from other card games
Gets free updates/expansions as far as I see (still have to buy packs)
Can get free packs/cards from just playing
Enjoyable deck builder with decient UI
Balanced races for the most partNeutral:
Reasonable Microtransactions (Buy Booster packs etc) and not necessary to winCons:
Story isn't extreamly interesting as ones like MTG
Final Suggestion:  Try it. It's free after all.

Rating:  8/10

Scale:  1 =AVOID [-|-]  2-4 =Try Only if Free [-|-]  5 =Meh, Could be Better
6 =Below Average [-|-]  7 =Average [-|-]  8 =Get if it appeals [-|-]  9 =Get it [-|-]  10 =MUST HAVE

reviewText:
This is a digital TCG, trading card game.  It has an in game item store but it seems you can play to earn all that you could buy, no buying wins in this game! The game mechanics are sound and the play speed is as fast as you want it to go.  I really enjoy this game due to the animation, the AI is good, you can unlock a ton of content in a few short hours, deck building is smooth and effortless, and the campaigns are very well put together.  The game has PVP, campaign, and practicing against AI.
I highly recommend this game as it was FREE.  9.5/10 fun factor and great replayablity.  Graphics and sound both get 7.5/10.

A+ game!

reviewText:
Back in Febraury 2014, I came into the game and never stopped playing.  Over the months, many changes happened, and this year, I have seen a lot of less players than usual.  It is beginning to take a long time to get into a game since no one is around anymore.  I am going to tell you the good sides of this game when players are on.

Good parts of this game if players actually play the game.
-Of course, less time-taking on finding a game.
-More ideas from feedback.
-Better chance of finding glitches that everyone hates, which contributes to the hate of this game.
-The trading community would be more thriving.
-Less chance of a new player competing against a Pay-to-Win player with major experience.
-An overall strong community.
-More interesting features and updates would have greater appreciation.
-More people could help new players entering the game.


Summer 2014-The Ascension update comes out with a whole new faction to play around.  The Overseers, one of the most game-changing factions.  Hundreds of new players were around and everything was just great, until the new faction was too overpowered for everyone to handle (Try out my old 2014 rebellion deck, which completly devastated the overseers).  Soon, since there were so many players complaining about this problem, the creators got the message quickly and balanced the faction when Order came out.

Here are some of the bad things in this game.
-Pay to Win (Mainly because only the Pay-to-Win players still play the game).
-In-game issues, causing both players to sometimes immediatly get kicked off the game.
-The shop.
-Takes too long to find a game.
-The uncommons are more powerful than rares.


To make this game better, everyone interested in Trading Card Games should give it a try, which could make a whole lot of new players joining the game, concluding in the increase of gameplay and feedback.  I rate this game 10/10 in 2014 and 8/10 on present day.

reviewText:
As a player of Magic the Gathering, I always felt that MTG lacked depth because of it's singular approach of reducing your oppositions life pool to zero. I disregard decking as a legitimate method of winning because it is simply not as practical.

Infinity Wars resolves this issue by adding the morale pool in addition to a life pool. This addition of a morale pool creates more opportunities for creative deck building. A defensive deck is as legitimate as an offensive build. The simultaneous turns also improves the flow of the game and creates some interesting possibilities.

The Gameplay is solid and the Free to Play structure is done well and allows a player to enjoy without paying, although buying items in the store is tempting for the same reason I have amassed giant MTG collections.

The art direction is visually pleasing and the animated cards communicate the idea of the art well, both humorous and serious  ideas come across well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This is the first review I've done, bear with me.)
This game card game is unlike any card game I've ever played before: Magic: The Gathering, Shadow Era, Pokemon TCG, Yu-Gi-Oh, WarStorm. Of all the Card games I played, this one brings a new, unique play that is not seen in any other Card game before. This game involves a simultaneous action on both players on same phases: Both players draw a card at the same time, both players plan out their approach and tactic in the game and both players will see the results of their planning. This Card game is very fast paced and and you don't have to do all that waiting for your opponent to finish and start your turn. Also the music you are immersed on during gameplay and even during the menu gives a nice feeling towards the animations of the cards.

This is not a P2W. You will also be given free booster packs as with everyone else and a chance to do so everyday with your daily wins. Also, after playing through the campaign, you will be given a starter deck of their respective factions so you won't need to do alot of collecting for a pure faction deck as it will be given for you. And the achievement system also allows you to get more cards alot of the campaign achievments give a free card.

This game does have it's bugs and glitches, but it's still improving. It will get better, in time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Solid card game with a lot of variance to create unique decks.  Of course like any card game some cards are much better than others, but devs look to be active in keeping the game as balanced as it can be.  Able to earn a decent amount of cards if played regularly and have bought card packs from the 1st expansion and was able to build a fairly solid deck.  The biggest fault in the game is not auction/trading house, but just a trading channel.  This to me is the biggest reason I would rate this about a 6.5/10.  If they are able to add a solid auction/trading house would not hesitate to give it a 9/10.

There is a bit of a pay to win, but enough solo that seems to be expanding so you can still get to a solid level to compete against others, just a tad bit slower.  Have played a few card games and this one seems the most balanced so far I have played.

Invite Code 1269F and feel free to add me ingame.

reviewText:
As a player of Magic the Gathering, I always felt that MTG lacked depth because of it's singular approach of reducing your oppositions life pool to zero. I disregard decking as a legitimate method of winning because it is simply not as practical.

Infinity Wars resolves this issue by adding the morale pool in addition to a life pool. This addition of a morale pool creates more opportunities for creative deck building. A defensive deck is as legitimate as an offensive build. The simultaneous turns also improves the flow of the game and creates some interesting possibilities.

The Gameplay is solid and the Free to Play structure is done well and allows a player to enjoy without paying, although buying items in the store is tempting for the same reason I have amassed giant MTG collections.

The art direction is visually pleasing and the animated cards communicate the idea of the art well, both humorous and serious  ideas come across well.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAfter seeing some videos online and the recent reviews, I decided to give Infinity Wars a whirl myself. I can say it's definitely a fun game. The gameplay itself i unique while not alienating players who've tried other popular card games . They also add a lot of personality and life to cards by giving each of them an animation. The game is still in beta, so there are kinks they need to iron out, sometimes when adding a new card to your deck it might be marked illegal the next time you log in and you may need to take it out and put it in again, and sometimes it may take a while to find a match; but these are minor complaints that I'm sure they'll iron out in the future. Also, the game isn't Pay 2 win; their are know major cash shop items that give you a major advantage. Sure, you can buy card packs with real money, but your better off just buying them with the in game currency, it doesn't take that long  (plus you get a free card pack when you level up and sometimes as a daily win award.) If you like card games, this is definitely one you should give a try.

reviewText:
If there is a neutral option, I will give that instead.

The game is fairly interesting, and the single player content will eat up 15+ hours. The game is fairly complex as well.
The pay to win factor is there, which is a huge downside, but pay to win applies to both digital and non-digital collectable card games anyways :( So in order to match up with long time vets who grinded long enough to get all the good cards/pay to win people, you better just start grinding and finish all the single player stuff.
The server is quite unstable.

Pros:
+Great digital card game with animated cards
+Complex but bearable
+Free :D
+Great art
+Free cards upon finished single player contents, enough to start customizing decks
+A lot of single player content

Cons:
-Obvious pay to win potential
-Not really beginner friendly
-Encourages trading cards, which makes people sell cards
-Buggy

Only recommended to those who love card games regardless of fair game or not.

Full Review

Best TCG ever  in terms of mechanics and startegy ,every other TCG out there is a distant second. This game is the best as well as my fav. But the bugs , sheer negligence of the community by devs  has ruined this masterpiece.

WHAT IW can offer that no one else can

Animated cards - Seriously at first they dont seem too big of deal but once you get used to it you wont be able to go back to any other game, the art of some cards is really amazing

Game mechanics - the presence of 4 diffrent zones ( command zone is an IW exclusive thing and is a game changer) , the purity combinations (the fact that you can mix diffrent classes adds so much verstality to the game )

Morale as a winning condition - In almost every game Health" is the decisive parameter using which a victory is abtained but IW adds another parameter "Morale"
date:
Its not only the  health of your fortress you have to take care of but also the morale of your army allowing immense variety of strategies and playstyles

THE FLAWS

Looks Shabby - The cards look amzaning but overall the game looks quite dull

Bugs - This game has a lot of bugs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is exactly what you are looking for.
So you like TCGs, PvP card games, awesome conceptual art + animation, and the thrill of victory?  Why on Earth isn't this game already in your Library?  It's free to play, the patch as of March 12, 2014 makes obtaining a solid card collection VERY easy, the campaign and quest objectives are continuously challenging when you just want to test your deck, and it is so easy to find yourself glued to your mouse on your fifth draft wondering when the addiction started.
Praise aside, this game is still in beta.  There happens to be plenty of transparency regarding what is currently not working well, what fixes are on-deck vs. long term, the game devs road map for progression, and highly active and public support from staffers.  Tech support is usually within 24 hours (the high volume around major patch days are obviously slower) and QA / Marketing members are active in streaming, vid casting, and the in game global chat.

reviewText:
A great online card game that does not just multiplayer, but single player right.

Highlights

- Infinity Wars has an extensive tutorial is well crafted.

- Aside from the tutorial there is the Academy which sets you in different scenarios and you must utilize the cards you have and the mechanics you have been taught to survive and win the match. (Reminds me of Dead Man's Hand from MTG)

- There is a campaign with eight different factions each with eight individual missions.

- Online play is great with normal and ranked play.

-Simultaneous turns is a great concept.

+Pros
Solid amount of single player content.

Great card animations.

Solid gameplay mechanics.

All cards and decks can be purchased with earned currency.

-Cons

Some of the artwork... just silly.

Additonal card backs and battlefields are only available for purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Having played many other Trading Card Games, Infinity Wars was a nice surprise. It offers a very unique experience that is enjoyable as well as challenging. The artwork and soundtrack are well done and compliment the game quite nicely. As far as learning curves go, it shouldn't take too long to start understanding the game, it helps to find a strategy that works for you. This is the first trading card game that I've seen to have a campagn, but it also has quick offline matches as well as multiplayer ones.

Conclusion:
If your looking for a free, unique Trading card game with nice graphics, nice soundtrack, and can be played both online (even has cross-platform multiplayer) and offline (campagn mode and quick matches), this is a great game to get! And after all, it is free so what are you waiting for? you shouldn't have been reading this message, you should've been downloading/playing this game!

Rating:
I give this game a 9/10

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nInfinity Wars has the complexity of a TCG like Magic the Gathering without being a clone of it, which is an accomplishment by itself. The mechanics are fun, and quite easy to learn with detailed rules and an in depth tutorial built right into the game. The animated card art is beautiful and never seems to get stale. You can get lost in the deck builder for hours, and it even lets you edit the starter decks. The business model is ridiculously generous for new players, giving you several free decks and dozens of cards for playing through the campaign without paying a dime. The grind for new booster packs can be a bit long after you finish the campaign however if you aren't looking to spend money. If you love card games though, Infinity Wars is a must try. Just beware of the occasional bugs like card art sticking to the screen that can interfere with a match, before dedicating time and resources to the draft or ranked modes.

reviewText: The card game itself is pretty excellent from a design perspective, which itself is quite a feat when it comes to electronic card games. Most of them are just tacked on after a terrible exploitative business model. It's better than games such as Magic the Gathering or Pokemon as it leaves open much more strategy and bluffing. However, like all e-card games, it has a terribly exploitative business model where the idea is to frustrate the player as hard as possible into buying packs. This comes in the following forms:\n\n-You earn packs as you level up" and complete campaigns. However
date: all these cards are locked from trading. This means they're useless unless they go in a workable deck for you personally. "Binds on equip"-style crap has bee cancerous since it was invented and needs to stop.\n\n-The conversion rate (in AUS dollars) for pack prices puts them at the same per-pack price and sometimes slightly higher than popular TCGs when purchased by the box. Anyone familiar with TCGs will know what I mean here. For everyone else
recommended: just know that in-game currency and real life money to spend on packs is heavily skewed out of your favor. Even with a fast deck
hoursPlayed: it takes 50 games to earn one pack of 15 cards.\n\n-The absolute monotonous grind. How would I know
voteText: given that I only have 4 hours on record? I watched my girlfriend play this game for 40 straight hours and her collection is still small

and of that maybe a tiny fraction is tradable. As tradable cards are only gotten through packs you buy expensively with real money or grind forever in-game.

-The new patch is going to make it even MORE grindy by lowering the initial pack cost a small percentage then dropping it from 15 cards to 5. Each card was previously worth 350 ingame currency on average but will now cost 600 currency on average. Screw that garbage.

In short

reviewText: First thing I want to clarify is that this game is not P2W which is a nice thing to say about a free-to-play game, infact it's a little too generous with the rewards (by the time you finish the tutorials and the campaign you already have 500+ cards). The game is easy to get into but also has a lot of depth, simultaneous turns allow for extra mindgames and whoever can read their opponent the best wins. Cards take full advantage of the fact that the game is digital so there's a lot of interesting and unique abilities to discover. Overall I think that this game should be more popular, but I guess the skill ceiling scares off new players (especially people who have never played TCGs before), also be ready to clean your schedule because Infinity Wars is very addicting :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing Hex, Scrolls, Hearthstone, Solforge, Duel of Champions, Conquest of Champions, and other new digital card games, I have to say that Infinity Wars is the best of them all. It strays the furthest from the MTG formula (unlike hex) without turning into a tabletop strategy game (scrolls/coc), and without oversimplifying the game (solforge/hearthstone). The addition of simultaneous turns and the division between attacking/defending/standby/command zones and their units makes this a really, really fun game with lots of opportunity for mindgames. There are a lot of strategic choices to be made in this game.

The other great part is that it is also contains all of the key components that make for a great digital card game:
Can you use one copy of a card in multiple decks? Yes.
Can you trade with other players? Yes.
Bots? Yes
Draft? Yes (and AI drafting practice!)
Campaign? Yes.
Leaderboards? Yes.
Game modes? How about a whole separate set of cards for playing with a Star Trek theme, future themes on the way, and queues for Star Trek games, standard deck games, mixed/infinity" deck games
date: merged deck games (both players combine decks and draw from combined pile)
recommended: and you can queue for all of those modes at once with different decks for each

reviewText:
1-) Best Alternative TCG to Hearthstone
2--) Easy to pick up impossible to master
3---) Great Meta throughout all Rankings
4----) Not pay to win; but incentives purchases

1) Infinity wars is imo one of the greatest cult classics among the lesser well known tcgs. (Hearthstone being the most popular as to exclude it) And other tcgs come close to it imo such as Hex : Shards of fate, Solforge, M&M, MTG; Although out of these i found that Infinity wars did not seem too convoluted in its system design; it was easy to pick up but hard to master. This was due to the almost gambling like turn system; where each players turns ended only when they accepted it. And when this happened, both players turns happened simultaneously. So in this perspect you can place some of your more valuable cards in safer zone. Pre-emptive moves among other intresting targeted spells would play together in this mash of motions.

2) The reason that it was easy to pickup and impossible to master was the fact that you were given the basic deck of cards from each faction upon completing its faction campaign. (more of an extended tutorial if you will) Which served as your barebones skeleton of to which build upon; and if you so fancied the starter deck expands upon this. Although it feels more like an intermediate deck of which stacks on your barebares campaign deck. It was also very plentiful with the amount of card packs it gave early on. (as level up gave card packs) Thus by the time you hit around lvl 10 you should have had plenty of cards of which you felt were very strong to compete with. And as the TCG mantra goes; more cards; more possiblities.

3) The meta of the game very deep and rich to say the least. This is because certain deck types almost always counter another deck type. And thus you had to either make you decks strengths more apparent, or your weaknesses less apparent. A good deck can get you carried higher in the ranks but as peoples understanding these inherent ideas grow; decks became harder and harder to counter. And thus there was always this arms race of sorts to pump up the RNG gods (random number game = equivlent to lady luck)

4)As stated earlier the reason this was not pay to win was becuase you were given the barebones of which to work with. And given pleniful amount of packs which slowed down as your cards grew from level ups (higher level = slower level up). Meaning that your earned currency to buy cards become more valuable and thus the payed currency. But this was fine as you will have amassed more cards when this spike occurs. Although the missing powerhouse in your decks made you crave more cards as a result.

9/10

reviewText:
So I'll try to write a balanced review here based on my experience as a casual trading card gamer. Forgive me if some of the dynamics reviewed are nothing new to a veteran gamer, as this review may be more helpful to the former.

First off this is a very enjoyable game, especially starting out. The tutorials are generally very helpful and progressive, moving you further along the game's style of play, which can also be said about the campaign. There are around 8 factions that you can start out with at any point, and upon completing mission 3 of that factions' campaign you will get a starter pack (not as full as a starter deck, which you can buy for about $7.50 or a significant amount of in-game currency).

I found the campaign to be very enjoyable, relatively challenging and scaled very well for difficulty. It can be easy at times, and then when you reach a mission where you might be struggling, as you reconsider the situation and/or play some of the other faction campaigns - and get their starter deck (for the missions allowing a custom deck) - you can progress. The campaign and academy missions tend to be puzzle"-like as the situation remains generally the same and the AI will play relatively the same each turn

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good alternative to Hearthstone and MTG that features stunning card animations and very unique gameplay.

Infinity Wars is an easy to learn but complex card game that focuses on winning in either two ways, destroy the enemy fortress (which has health) or kill enough of their minions and deplete enemy morale to zero, forcing their retreat. You choose 3 commanders, of whatever faction you wish, but depending on which cards you want to use, you will need a minimum amount of that factions commanders. An example would be having a specific faction card, lets say (Genesis) that requires you to have 2 of its factions commanders. For this card to be in your deck, you need 2 of those 3 required commanders to be of that faction, in this case Genesis. This allows for unique deck creation as you can have 1 commander from 3 different factions, allowing you to use faction cards with a required commander cost of 1, making it a unique and versatile deck. Or if your like me, use three commanders from the same faction and gain access to its extremely powerful cards.

Very noob friendly with a long and informative tutorial that is completely optional to do, but I would highly recommend completing the first two sections to make sure you understand the game. The third is for more advanced play, and can take upwards of an hour to complete, due to learning how to use special game mechanics.

To make sure you aren't getting destroyed, multiplayer VS people is disabled until you reach level 4, which will take roughly 1:30 - 2:00 hours to finish.

There is a long campaign that is interesting and very fun, which allows you to play every faction in the game to better learn its playstyle and get comfortable with the cards they command. Or if you feel like killing computers for that much wanted experience, just play the AI over and over until you reach the required level.

No Pay 2 Win, you can pay for decks and booster packs with real money or use the in game currency to buy cards. (like most online TGC) If you do choose to sink money into IW, the prices are very reasonable and you get a good amount of cards added to your collection.

Low player base, as its probably not very popular with the current kings of cards being MTG and more recently, Hearthstone.

If you were to ask me to explain Infinity Wars in a sentence, it would be (Its like the middle grounds of Hearthstone and Magic: The Gathering: animated cards, complex at times, simple to learn and very fun to play)

Personal Rating: 4/5
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game has finally done what every other online tcg should have been doing from the beginning; every single card is animated. I actually enjoy just looking through and appreciating the awesome art work and watching the cool little animations. I also really love how every deck feels completely broken when it goes off; It's a total power trip!\nOne of my favorite and most unique features is when you play a location card and your side of the board transforms to match it; it looks awesome! The different factions each represent different deck strategies that you're probably familiar with. The flame Dawn Army is your Big Red Aggro deck, playing a lot of fast creatures to win the game before your opponent can stabilize. Genesis Industries is a robot synergy deck that lets you play cheap guys who eat each other to get bigger. The Warpath uses really cheap big guys to smash through your opponent's creatures and in to the win zone. The Cult of Verore is a control deck that makes it's own creatures stronger by killing yours. The Descendants of the Dragon is a turbo fog control deck that uses all kinds of defenses to frustrate your opponent until you literally win the game by draining his morale or playing a giant unstoppable dragon. The sleepers of Avarrach is one of the best, coolest and most viable zombie decks of any tcg I've seen. Using recursion and graveyard effects to help you amass an overwhelming horde of the undead. The Exiles are demons who reward you when you discard cards from your hand or sacrifice creatures. All in all, you should DEFINITELY check out this game; if only to see the cards.

reviewText:
Infinity Wars - Animated Trading Card Game
Icy's Score: 5.2

Title: Infinity Wars - Animated Trading Card Game
Developer: Lightmare Studios
Category: Card
Rating: NOT RATED
Compatibilty: Windows, Mac
Price: FREE

Gameplay:
Look at the gameplay video above for more info (made by MMOBomb), but this game is a Trading Card Game like Hearthstone. And I first thought this when I first played but this game has its own distinct feel. First of all, you have cards, every turn you get usage point. You start off with 1 which you get less powerful cards but each turn goes up by 1 so soon enough you will have very powerful cards but like all card games, its all about setting a foundation. The board is set up in 2 areas: The left is your defense zone (or your opponents attack zone), you put cards there to stop your opponents from killing you but if you don't put any cards there to stop your opponent you will get hurt. The right is your attack zone (or your opponents defense zone), its the opposite of your defense zone. If you put cards there you will fight the other opponents cards but if your opponents cards aren't there then you hit the player if you get its HP to 0, you win.

Graphics:
As the title says, this game is animated. And the animation is pretty nice, it has its distinct feel and fits this sci-fi atmosphere. I like it, definately when the cards have a little clip in them.

Controls & Smoothness:
The whole game uses the mouse, you  drag cards out but I found that you have to drag the cards out precisely it won't work.

Music & Sound:
The sound effects are pretty nice though I find a huge lack in music variety and nothing stood out.

Difficulty:
I found that the campaign was very limited to its playstile. As this is a card game, everybody plays the game differently but if you want to pass it you have to be full on offense and no defence if you want to pass the campaign. Which I found very annoying as your meant to develop your own playstyle.

Fun Level:
I found this game fun when you were playing your own way which was really fun but the campaign would throw away a lot of players as there is only one type of style to beat it.

In conclusion, this game is great and really has a twist on the card genre, but until they can fix the muddled campaign, its hard to recommend this.

Pro's:
- Nice animations
- Free
- A nice twist on the card genre makes the gameplay awesome

Con's:
- Awful and muddled campaign
- Lacking soundtrack

Score: 5.2

reviewText:
Outstanding variation in terms of deck building. There is NO limit to how many different decks you can build and save, so you can customize and try out new ideas as much as your heart desires.

The simultaneous turns takes a little getting used to, but allow for some really unique plays.

Free to play aspect is solid. 1 card for logging in daily, 1 card for 3 games played daily, weekly quests, free packs on leveling up, and in game currency for playing matches. Has drafting which can earn you good rewards if you do well.

Unranked matches are Bo1 with no sideboard
Ranked Matches are Bo3 with sideboard.

reviewText:
I did like it at first, but the single player was greatly toned down recently. Albeit the fact that the new single player is a bit more user-friendly, it's not so hard hitting--you are babied into playing Infinity Wars. Also it is much smaller than before. Multiplayer is good for the most part. You get cards when leveling up and you can also buy them.  However, don't expect to get anything besides cards for free. Card backs, game textures, and avatars all require you to spend real money for them, which is a big con compared to games like Hearthstone. A few pluses to mention. All cards are animated and the game has great music!

Keeping this review slim.
TL,DR: No cosmetics are free, no singleplayer. Animated cards are cool, but better off playing Hearthstone unless you really, REALLY like multiplayer card games.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
In my experience Infinity Wars is just another a free to play / pay to win trading card game that does not deliver enough variety and challenge to make it count.

The free card packs that you get for hours and hours of play contain always the same basic cards you already have.

Premade decks have some interesting ideas but you can recognize the likeness with other decks mechanics from other classic TCGs.

For me this game is not worth the time.
