reviewText:
The game would be very nice if only the interface was more polished and user friendly. As it is now, for the new player it is very difficult to get up to speed.

when enemy plays card (or activates ability) it is unclear what actually happens - their 5/5 creature suddenly changes into 20/20 and I have no idea what caused it
it is not possible to view all cards you own, you can only see the cards that would fit into your currently selected deck
the list of cards you select from is a horizontal scrollable list instead of grid - you can see at most 10 cards at a time
the deck I have constructed is illegal, but there is no any information why
the play screen is very unclear, I have no idea whether I am playing campaign or some side mission and what the rewards might be. Regarding the campaign, there is no list of missions, just multiple maps and have fun finding icons on it...

reviewText:
Wow. This is just an all around excellent game.
The artwork is wonderful, the game play is straight forward and intuitive.
I found myself 9 hours in before I knew what hit me.
Tutorials are good and show you the basics of operation, without going too granular in scope.
Simultaneous turns are a great new wrinkle. AI is challenging and actually fun to play against, when you lose you learn something!
Deck building is easy and fun. It is a keeper.

NOT PAY TO WIN!!!! <-- I cannot stress this enough

I would buy this free game again! :P

The best TCG/CCG I have seen out there. period.

12/10  an actual good game, all for the cost of free. Come get you some.

reviewText:
It's a solid CCG with some new tricks up its sleeve. I've had a lot of fun playing it, though players who pay will get the cards they want quicker than others. If you're one of those, however, the prices are actually very affordable.

-Update-
After spending some more time ingame, it seems like the draft mode is one of the most popular anyway, so there's really no need to pay to enjoy the Hell out of this game.

The game's in a semi-beta state, so if you're gonna get in on it, now's the time.

reviewText:
I work as a professional audio engineer, and the voice over work in this game is abysmal. There are plosives, lots of mouth and tongue clicks (aka mouth noise), and every voice sounds like it was recorded on totally different equipment. Most likely they just hired low cost voice over people from the internet, and each one is using a different standard of equipment. Acting is also sub par. I would have rather had no voices that distracting, low quality voices. Additionally, there are various typos throughout the system. The most obvious one I saw was the word 'availiable' (yes, with two 'i's) in the opening tutorial. Nice.

On to game play, I'm a long time TCG player of various games, and this one is just a cheap knock off of Hearthstone, which is already a fairly boring game for those who are used to more complex and exciting games like MTG. Game play itself is marred by a very confusing turn system (which is unexplained and un-intuitive to new comers). I found myself stuck on the tutorial level where it says 'attack with all' and there is simply no button that says 'attack' or 'proceed' or 'go'. The fact that I have to carefully scan the screen for several minutes, check the options menu, and finally just give up shows a complete failure in this aspect.

It's pretty clear the developers here only cared for making shiny graphics and animations, and cared nothing for the audio, the user interface, or even proper spelling.

reviewText: I can't believe I had to find this thing out from the Steam reccomendations page. This game should be talked about far more widely. If you enjoy magic or any similar card games, please try this out, it needs far more love. It is free to play, but not pay to win, as a glance at the store can tell you. The in game currency is handed out pretty regularly, the only pay exclusive items are for appearance (card backs, backgrounds). The campaign itself is wonderfully well made, with the the early stages teaching you how to play the deck the campaign is based around, and later stages relying on you coming up with interesting card combinations to win an otherwise one sided fight. The art is great, the game balance (as far as I can tell so far) is damn well done, and the updates seem regular. Please give it a try!\n\nUPDATE: As an update: 2 months in of playing it practically everyday, and it still hasn't gotten old. Finished the entire campaign, which teaches you rather well how to play each faction and various deck strategies they use. The AI opponents are rather dumb once you play against them enough, but PVP is very fun, and not the least bit stressfull. Even if you lose, you still get way more experience and cash than the AI would give you, and its very quick and easy to play the 3 games you need to get the second free card a day. With weekly quests to give you more free cards, and the 2 daily ones having a chance of being anything from a common to an epic (got 2 already this way), it never feels like you're stagnating. You can always build new decks and try new strategies, it doesn't hurt you to lose (in unranked anyway), and if you don't feel like that, there are always the rotating decks to try out, with varying difficulties of use. So to reiterate, if you like card games, play it!

If your'e a casual player, dont waste your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a trading card game that is beautiful and you'll need to bring some strategics to the board.
I've played this game and Heartstone. I prefer IW to heartstone. because this seems to have a bit more depth.

I find the diversity in IW a big pro. Also not necessary to buy any cards - because you get quite some free booster packs by achieving stuff (single player campaign, pvp games, by logging in every day and/ or playing three matches).

There are a lot of different gameplays (merged for example merges both players decks, rifting which will build a deck befoe you start - and with that one you need to keep winning as much as possible, before losing 3 times).

I did purchase some booster packs to help the development - and to enhance my chance on a few cool cards. But really it's completely playable (the campaign) without any purchases - just finished the campaign.

Apart from the regular cards, there are also star trek:tng cards - you do need to purchase that if you want. But apart from adding ST:TNG to your deck it's just cards, that you don't really need  of course.

The selection of cards to build a deck could be better, but since the game is only in beta - i imagine that this will improve in the next period.

All in all - if you like trading card games, i highly recommend this. My referralcode is F9DD5. But the referral system is not yet active - because it's still beta.

The game itself is stable, fun, intelligent and... well fun.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlot similiar to Hearthstone as they have a 30 card Sealed/Draft Format where you select 1 of 3 cards for your deck. You gain 1 resource a turn so no screwed games due to lack of resources. Pretty Balanced for as new as the game is as every single card has a use in a deck from what I have seen. The ability to have 3 commanders can be a little overpowered as some of them should be banned and not be commanders IMO. But I think its an upgraded version of hearthstone with a much larger selection of cards but instead of having class restrictions you have race restrictions which you can still create hybrid decks. Solid size enviorment I havent had any trouble finding a game in constructed or limited/draft I havent had to wait longer than 10 seconds for a game. Overall great game if you enjoy these type of card games and I strongly reccomend to anybody who enjoys hearthstone as its a step up. Game needs more advertisement though I think it has potential to be the best of its kind. Also message me if you enjoy this review and I can give you a reference code to play and it would help me out a ton :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome Game probably the best Digital TCG I have played, compared to Hearthstone it is much more competitve in nature. The game has more of a  strategy and prediction aspect with their simulatneous action phases. Infinity War's has an extensive card collection already and enough factions to keep people interested. Overall I really enjoy this game, especially for anybody that felt Hearthstone may have been a bit to childish or not competitve enough it seems as if Lightmare will be supporting the competitive community in their game.

The rules are fairly simple and easy to pick up especially for anybody used to playing tcg's such as magic. The Art on the cards is great and while some of the animations are a bit lack luster some are also fantastic. Playerbase is beyond great all of the older players are helpful and support the new players with what they can and I haven't seen any rude players yet. Lightmare is being very open and clear about their plans for the game without giving to much away which I like as well.

Overall : 8.5/10 would definatly give it a try!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome Game probably the best Digital TCG I have played, compared to Hearthstone it is much more competitve in nature. The game has more of a  strategy and prediction aspect with their simulatneous action phases. Infinity War's has an extensive card collection already and enough factions to keep people interested. Overall I really enjoy this game, especially for anybody that felt Hearthstone may have been a bit to childish or not competitve enough it seems as if Lightmare will be supporting the competitive community in their game.

The rules are fairly simple and easy to pick up especially for anybody used to playing tcg's such as magic. The Art on the cards is great and while some of the animations are a bit lack luster some are also fantastic. Playerbase is beyond great all of the older players are helpful and support the new players with what they can and I haven't seen any rude players yet. Lightmare is being very open and clear about their plans for the game without giving to much away which I like as well.

Overall : 8.5/10 would definatly give it a try!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely amazing. I'm a MtG veteran (over 10 years of playing Magic the Gathering) and I never saw a PC card game made so amazingly good. Lately I tried Heartstone just to be seriously dissapointed by it - mostly becasue of the poor mechanics (game is very, very random - and card rarity driven). Although playing for free in Heartstone was perfectly possible it's nowhere near the complexity and strategic depth of Infinity Wars.

I'm in total amazement, how small group of people could make something better than Blizzard. I recommend this to all card game lovers, and to people who like to think while playing.

For extra currency and cards use 700C2 code while creating an account.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt this time I have only played an hour of this game, but oh my is it amazing. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEarly access is running nicely.  Its quite easy to get into but seems to require deeper thought to master.  For a F2P online TCG, obtaining new cards is systematically well done and is even as simple as playing through the starting tutorials, campaign missions, and of course online multiplayer.  So far, the rewards for each match (win or lose) are plentiful including tokens that reveal single cards and booster packs as well as in-game points that can later be traded for more cards (boosters and decks).  I am only at level three and have already obtained about 5 or so uncommon and 3 rare cards, not to mention over sixty commons that seem to all be quite useful.  As a former player of both Yu-Gi-Oh (simi-competitively) and Magic The Gathering (more casually), I must say that it is immensely refreshing to play Infinity Wars.  The mechanics are fun and intuitive and the turn structure makes for much room to outsmart your opponents and keep them guessing.  In attempt to not spoil the game and all that it has to offer, I will simply say give it a shot!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlot similiar to Hearthstone as they have a 30 card Sealed/Draft Format where you select 1 of 3 cards for your deck. The ability to have 3 commanders can be a little overpowered as some of them should be banned and not be commanders IMO. But I think its an upgraded version of hearthstone with a much larger selection of cards but instead of having class restrictions you have race restrictions which you can still create hybrid decks. Solid size enviorment I havent had any trouble finding a game in constructed or limited/draft I havent had to wait longer than 10 seconds for a game. Overall great game if you enjoy these type of card games and I strongly reccomend to anybody who enjoys hearthstone as its a step up. Game needs more advertisement though I think it has potential to be the best of its kind. reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a trading card game that is beautiful and you'll need to bring some strategics to the board.
I've played this game and Heartstone. I prefer IW to heartstone. because this seems to have a bit more depth.

I find the diversity in IW a big pro. Also not necessary to buy any cards - because you get quite some free booster packs by achieving stuff (single player campaign, pvp games, by logging in every day and/ or playing three matches).

There are a lot of different gameplays (merged for example merges both players decks, rifting which will build a deck befoe you start - and with that one you need to keep winning as much as possible, before losing 3 times).

I did purchase some booster packs to help the development - and to enhance my chance on a few cool cards. But really it's completely playable (the campaign) without any purchases - just finished the campaign.

Apart from the regular cards, there are also star trek:tng cards - you do need to purchase that if you want. But apart from adding ST:TNG to your deck it's just cards, that you don't really need  of course.

The selection of cards to build a deck could be better, but since the game is only in beta - i imagine that this will improve in the next period.

All in all - if you like trading card games, i highly recommend this. My referralcode is F9DD5. But the referral system is not yet active - because it's still beta.

The game itself is stable, fun, intelligent and... well fun.

reviewText: At the time of this review i have logged 41 hours on this game. Infifnity Wars is an amazing tcg with new inivative mechanics combined with astounding animated are for each card. the turns are taken simaltainiously with both players having the same amount of rescources at the stard of the match, this game features a double win condidtion style of players which alters which faction and type of deck you play. This is what seperates this game from other tcgs.\nhowever it has 1 shortcoming- you need to spend a lot of time with this game to get anywhere in a pvp ranked envornment  (Without spending Money) this is because of the in-game Currency nothing really wrong with it except the average game win gives you 150-170 IP (Infinity Points) which would not be a problem if it were not for the OUTRAGOUS cost of a free to play pack at a whopping 5,400 IP which would mean i would need to win around 40 pvp matches to get even one. leveling gives you packs but with increasing amount of XP you need they are few and far apart. the paid price is reasonable at a $2.50 ratio and when you perchase the paid currency it gives you some IP as well depending on how much money you spend.\nyou could do an endless grind to get packs but the game feels like its pushing you to become a paid user and if you dont you fall behind because new sets are released at an average rate and cards that you own may become useless. also the cards you earn with Leveling up cannot be traded. trading in this game is hard to do because of the tier list that are mademany poeple ive traded with use different tier lists so card value feels non-existant at best. (this of corse depends on who you trade with.) Its fun to play and i'd recommend it for any TCG player 8/10

reviewText: Now, I'm not one for writing these reviews in all honesty, but I feel the need to write something for a game that I've been pretty faithful to lately, I was playing the Beta and I was practically addicted to it during that time, I would refuse to turn off my laptop in order to play a game or two. I personally love this game, I love all the different factions and their own unique playstyles, And how almost every deck has counter-play right now, they are fairly balanced at this point in time. If you're looking for a genuine free to play game, this is one that you'll enjoy. While I can say that it gets a little tedious at times trying to get the packs you need for new cards, but that's where I like the 'Master & Apprentice' system, it's basically a system where you can play with someone you've met, or invited to the game to be either your Master or Apprentice, and for each 15 minutes of play in game with that person, you both get a 'blister pack', you also gain all the rewards of playing an actual PvP game, but you get to play it with a friend! Oh how glorius this it! XD (Sorry for my poor English at points, It's not my 'native' tongue.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let it be known I am already a fan of ccg.

That being said, Infinity wars has a lot to offer any strategy minded individual. As a ccg it has some interesting features, bearing familiar elements for those adept with ccg already. There are 7 main factions, a unallied faction whose cards can be included in any deck, and of course, the amazing Star Trek expansion.

Deck building is virtually unrestricted - a legal deck must have three 'Commander' cards, which determine the types of cards you can include in your deck, and at least 40 cards.  Each card has an affinity cost, and as long as you have enough generals of the appropriate type in your command slot, you can put that card in your deck. A maximum of three copies of any card can be included, but you can break that rule by also putting those cards in your command zone (protip). There are also unlimited cards, which as their nomiker indicates, can be included in any number.

Now where IW excels is that, while rare or epic cards can seriously affect the battlefield, some of the most effective decks I've run or come across use common, or even unlimited cards. I've had marked success in both ranked mode and tournament play, which are single pvp battles. These are further restricted by set types, including five different types of deck restrictions. Within these, if you are concerned about pay-to-win decks, there is even a merged deck mode, which shuffles both players card sources together, theoretically limiting the effectiveness of people with scads of cash.

However, the game is balanced enough (imo) to not require such drastic measures. The draft mode as well is extremely fun, and also (if you do well) seems to be the best mode of earning the in game currency. Drafting players select three commanders from 3 4 card choices, and then draft a deck from cards that will come up in the same 4 card options. This means 0 wait time, as you are not dependant on other players to make desicions, you just draft, and then can queue up for matches at your own convenience. 3 losses and you are out, but the better you do, the more you earn. Once you accumulate 3 losses the game offers you the choice to purchase your deck, with cost reductions based on how well you did, and taking your entry fee into account.

Anything purchasable in the game can be bought with the silver coins you earn from playing the game normally (infinity points) or by purchasing Lightmare points (terrible name) with actual cash. While grinding infinity points, apart from draft, is sloooooooooow, (more o's are really needed, but just imagine them) that is hopefully due to the fact that the game is still in Beta. No good getting people all jacked out too soon as of yet is the reasoning I figure. That being said, after beating the campaign mode, the tutorial/challange mode, and participating in 2 drafts, I have close to 600 cards. That's a lot of options.

This game packs in a ton of great features for being free. I downloaded it about a week ago, have a full time job, and have still logged 50+ hours. I have not regretted the ZERO dollar investiment, and it's pebbles to download. I run it in windowed mode with an average pc, and can still do whatever else I like while I destroy people in pvp. If you like strategy games, get this. If you like ccg, you are actually missing out if you don't start playing this. Immediately.

This is already way too long (most have you have stopped reading) but if you still are, one final note. I have spent all my in game cash on booster packs of Star Trek, b/c hell yeah Star Trek. So far I've managed to peel Commander Riker, Data twice, and mother-trucking Q himself. Now I ask, and tell me true - Why WOULDN'T you want to play a  card game where you can play WIll Riker and beat people down with him? Why?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a nutshell:  Infinity Wars is a great game, and I'd highly recommend it to anyone wanting a deep strategy card experience.

**

At first I was playing Infinity Wars and Hearthstone, and I was vacillating between the two.  Then I gave Infinity Wars a dedicated afternoon, and that's all she wrote.  Now it's Infinity Wars and nothing else.

When you first start playing you don't realize how many subtle mechanics there are that really allow a deep level of strategy and custom deck building.  Once you do; however, you quickly come to appreciate how intricate and sophisticated this game can be (and I mean that in a very good way!).  There are also a TON of cards and card combinations, so anyone who enjoys building a unique, custom deck is going to be in hog heaven.

When you do give this game a try don't be put off by the generic feeling tutorial and beginner campaign decks.  These are simple on purpose I believe to ease beginners into the game.  Once you have the basics under your belt try searching the web for some custom deck ideas.  You'll quickly see the amazing amount of different ways you can put together a devious combination of cards to wreck havoc on your opponent.

And did I mention the daily log in rewards, quests, tournaments, ranked play, leveling rewards, etc. etc.?  This game has a lot going for it to keep you engaged, and it's an indie title too boot.  You can't lose on that!

So, in summary:  This is a fantastic game, and if you should definitely give it a shot.  I'll bet you'll be hooked in no time.  :)

And feel free to hit me up for a game anytime.

reviewText:
Infinity Wars is one of the greatest digital TCGs... scratch that.
Infinity Wars is one of the greatest TCGs I have ever played, and I have played my fair share.
This game is not for those who are only seeking a casual experience (seriously, go play Hearthstone or one of those web-based games), Infinity Wars has a great level of depth to the gameplay that can only be found in simultaneous turns. Imagine fusing competitive pokemon with its simultaneous turns (leading to prediction wars, 50/50s, and a very intense experience) with MTG (factions with very different tools that work together to create hundreds of possible strategies).

Ok, so currently its not the most balanced game ever. The exiles faction is bothering many players with its RNG elements. HOWEVER this is not as serious a problem as many take it to be. This is not like Magic where any deck that isn't OP will never win. You can get by with a limited card pool without dropping $100 plus. This game is completely free to play. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Highly recommended, Infinity Wars is a TCG where you build decks of cards revolving around different factions and fight against AI and other players. There are various modes in the game and plenty of cards to boot. You have a chance of getting a free card or rarely, a booster pack of 15 cards in it every day just by logging in and an extra card by playing the first 3 games of the day.
The campaign mode of the game focuses heavily on strategy and bolstering of player skills so that you are fully prepared when you face PVP. In PVP there is also a random draft mode where you pay a moderate amount to enter. Once you enter you create a 40 card deck to face off against players and after each you gain rewards. But after 3 losses you are out of the game and you have the option to purchase the deck you created. The more you win the cheaper the deck becomes at the end and after a certain number of wins you can even get the deck for free.
What is also great about the game is that all the cards are obtainable without spending any money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to wait until I had a good few PvP matches under my belt to give this game a review and I have to say, this is one of the most fun card games to come out in a while. While it does fall under the Free to Play card game model of buying boosters to get cards, what this game does that many others don't is that it gives you plenty of cards to play with even if you don't purchase them. This is done by playing through the in-game campaign that unlocks a starter deck for each faction AND while you level up from playing, you get booster packs with each level (this is true up to my current level of 7, a booster at each level)

The free boosters are offset with the stipulation that the cards unlocked through free boosters and starter packs cannot be traded for other cards. This means to trade cards you must purchase them either through real cash or the in game currency LP (Light Points). As of now, I have bought 2 packs with real money and last night was able to buy my first pack through LP. I have to say that it feels satisfying, knowing that people do not get penalized for not spending cash on this game. People who do won't necessarily have an edge over other's, they just have more odds of getting Rare, Epic and Legendary cards through means of buying more packs.

As for gameplay, I really like the feel of the game. There's 2 ways to win; Destroy their base or get their Morale to 0. Destroying their base is typical: assault them hard enough to break through their defenses. Morale gives a different spin on things where with each loss of a unit, they lose a certain amount of Morale. If Morale hits 0, they also lose. I found this to be particularly interesting when I won a game through this way without actually trying. I had a decently strong offensive built and the only way my opponent could survive was through mass small units of defense that were just there to block my attacks, they also respawned each round. They held off my offense for quite a long time but with each unit that died, they lost Morale. Ultimately, they saved their Fortress but lost so many units in the process, their Morale hit 0 and I won. I thought that was pretty neat.

PvP seems to be a good mish-mash of different decks and styles of play. Some seem to counter others better. I'm no pro at games like these but I enjoy them and I'm hesitant to play PvP since I, like most people, don't like to be dominated in any game. In my experience thus far I've won more games than I've lost and what's better is you learn certain tactics by seeing how others play this game.

As with many card based games, there's a lot of rules you have to digest, but if you stick with it, go through the Campaign and Academy modes, you will learn a lot and have a hell of a lot of fun playing this game. I can't recommend this game high enough.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best TCG on PC ever in my opinion! Simultenious turns system is quite fun and works perfectly on PC. All the cards are animated, it satifies players when you play a powerful dragon card and see it actually flying into the battlefield and dominate everything!

Compared to other TCG games so far, MTG has an outdated UI and it's really annoying to click 7-9 times a turn due to the instant spell system. It works well in offline game but doesn't fix the digital TCG game. Hearthstone has a well-designed voice acting and UI, but the game itself is way too simple, you just play and see your luck, nothing more depth deck building or playing.
DoC ( Duel of Champions ) is a great Magic & Might TCG game I've spent hours in it. The game is all right but it's a little bit Pay 2 win kind... You can't have a second deck building for a loooooong time if you didn't put money in it. And it's a pain to grind due to the lack of game mode.

Though it has some UI issues and Bugs right now, the game itself is quite promising! The rewards are good you could gain up to 600 cards simply finishing the campaigns ( and it's really easy), Deck building is fun and totally free, no more heroes limits! (in DoC you can only build you deck according to the heroes you have) , Game modes are plenty and challenging! If you are a card game lover, it is a game you can not miss!
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've decided to take a moment and recommend this game.  In its current state, infinity wars has more random bugs than any beta game I've ever played.  Perhaps what speaks most to the quality of this game is that I can't put it down despite those bugs.
Infinity wars is about trying things, failing, learning, and stomping some nerd in the face!  It seems like there are only a couple dozen or so truly viable strategies right now.  I suppose as the cards diversify, that'll change.  Battles are relatively quick, and its amazing how powerful the armies get.

Graphics aren't as professional as hearthstone or the might and magic tcg.  But the game has a definite style that is fun.  And, frankly, I'm having more fun with this game than I had with either of those.

One last note.  The game rewards you with free cards pretty frequently, including 1 random card for each daily login, daily win, weekly quests, experience gained (winning or losing gains some experience), beating the campaigns (this is where you'll get your base cards - a lot of them).  I've also received avatars as rewards, which surprised me, since usually aesthetic stuff is reserved for cash.

Try it out.  It's free to play.

reviewText:
So I have a little bit of a hard time deciding whether or not to recommend this game. On the one hand it has excellent game mechanics and in terms of strategic depth it's probably the best card game I've seen (including magic the gathering - also if you liked magic you will almost certainly love this game!).
That said the game doesn't have the largest player base anymore (only a few hundred people at a time now a days) and there are some noteworthy issues with it.

Rating of IW:

Mechanics: 9.5/10 (and I don't think I'd give anything a 10)

Strategic Depth: 9.5/10

Balance: 6 (it's not horrible and the margin by which it tends to favor certain builds isn't actually that big. But the meta has felt pretty similar for a long time).

Welcoming to new players: Game 1/10; Community 7-8/10. This game takes a lot of time to really get into. It's a great game but expect to put many hours into it to get a feel for the mechanics, tricks, meta, etc. (To give a rough idea I'd say you need to spend about 20hours on this game just to get a decent feel of it).

Developer Responsiveness: 6/10

Bugs: 5/10 (They aren't horrible, you can still play the game and most often don't run into them, but do expect to lose matches occasionally (around 1 in 50?) due to bugs that aren't going away anytime soon).

F2P: 9.5/10

So with regards to the mechanics/strategy. This game uses simultaneous turns and resources automatically increase up to 10. The resources thing is nice (particularly if you are coming from magic, no getting land sc***ed or mana glut) but it's really the simultaneous turns that make this game stand out. Both players que there turns at the same time, on a given turn one player has priority and priority switches player each turn. The order of play is as follows: upkeep and comes into play effects, premeptive abilities, regular abilities, attacking and the other player defending (each of those resolves for the player with priority and then the other player and each player gets to que the order in which their cards happen within those phases) - although it's a lot more streamline when playing it than what I just described sounds.
Since both players turns are qued at the same time and resolve without either player being able to react to them this introduces a lot of bluffing into the game. For example Which zone is this character going to be in? One were they can attack or defend or back in support where they are safer from my opponents removal cards?" A lot of the game has to do with correctly and consistently anticipating your opponents actions and winning a game has as much to do with deck construction as it does with accurately predicting your opponent (depending on the match the second one of these can be more important.. especially in draft formats).

Cards: Cards are quite diverse and comprable to magic the gather in terms of the range of their mechanics. (Noting that magic has something like 20 years on this game
date: so more like magic back in the mercadian masques block).\n\nWelcoming to new players: The community is pretty friendly and will generally be pretty nice to players (well
recommended: maybe not if a player is complaining to them about something that they aren't really the person it should be taken up with
hoursPlayed: but in general). That said the campaign and challenges (a.k.a. tutorial/single player) is pretty short and it takes a very long time to build up ones card pool. So starting out you will probably lose a lot. Try rift runs because at least then the card pool is statistically the same for you and your opponent
voteText: but you won't have the experience with the game that they do and still don't expect to win that much for awhile. Harsh I know
helpfulPercent: and lots of players (both new and old) have given feedback on how to improve that aspect but
votesHelpful: \n\nDeveloper Responsiveness: This is a game by a small indie company. They have a community manager and player support person (a different person for each of those). Both of those people are pretty on top of it and I do feel like the developers work pretty hard on the game behind the scenes. Also generally they do actually look at player feedback and address it... eventually. I've made several different suggestions (on rewording particular cards
votesTotal: new card ideas and various other things) as I've played the game and I've usually seen something addressing what I've mentioned (text being fixed to make it more clear
votesFunny: cards to fit slots that certain factions were lacking
commentsCount: etc). That said don't expect a quick response to anything that requires input on the devs side of things. My general feeling is that between coming up with new cards and fixing stuff that their small dev team is a bit overwhelmed and while they will get to stuff eventually it might take a few months - really pressing stuff is faster
column16: but don't be surprised if this thing you feel like is really pressing isn't pressing enough to get addressed quickly.\n\nBugs: The game is peer to peer
column17: meaning that desyncs will happen and when they happen lots of things will get screwed up and sometimes the match will just freeze (in game this is refered to as the endless turn bug/glitch). Most often this doesn't happen
column18: but expect it to happen about 1/50 matches on average and when it does happen expect it to either cost you or your opponent the game. This might eventually get fixed
column19: but from the communty managers responses/how long people have been complaining about it
column20: I wouldn't expect it to happen anytime soon (maybe in a couple of years?).\nThat aside the game isn't that buggy
column21: usually there are a few issues after a patch but they tend to get resolved within a few weeks and aren't too major (things doing a little bit different things than what the cards say
column22: UI scrolling being a little off
column23: etc).\n\nF2P (free to play): You get IP (in game currency for playing dependent upon how long you play (ip gain for a match caps at 5minutes into the match)) and eventhing in the game can be bought using IP. Also IP works out to being something like $3-4/hour in terms of spending real money on packs. Which is a pretty good rate considering that your getting that for just playing the game. That said
column24: when starting out you will run into people who seem to have all the cards and be able to do these decks that you don't feel like you'll ever have the cards for. In general those people have been playing for a long time. It requires a lot of time and/or money in order to get a good card pool and whether or not the person has been spending money or not if they have a good card pool they have probably played for quite some time (notice my almost 1300hours on the game and I didn't start until this game was advertized on steam). The game does favor more experienced players
column25: honestly less in the card pool issue (since there is a built in draft format that is a lot of fun and honestly better than ranked play
column26: at least in my opininon)
column27:
more in the fact that it's a deep strategy game and it takes time to learn how to play and then a lot more time to learn how to play well.


Overall it's a great game
column29: but I'd still strongly encourage checking it out if you have time. It's more one of those games to play for awhile
column30: get a good feel for and then come back to it now and then (I strongly encourage long breaks from it when you get bored with it)."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before reading this review I would like to announce that I have playedt around 50 Hours in the nonsteam Client. Also this is a long ♥♥♥ review.

This is a great TCG, To start with you get a free card or even a booster when you log on, and after 3 games you get another card/ booster. You also get a booster every time you level up (A booster of 15 Cards) and your 1st 10 levels are faily fast to obtain. You also get a starter deck for each faction for getting 5 levels into each campaign and a booster for each mission finished. You also get a faction booster (Generaly 3-5 Cards) every time you level in a faction.
So right away you get a hardfull of cards within the 1st few hours of gameplay. Not to mention if you were to buy the boosters with real world money they have great value (In my opinion) It also only take a few hours of gameplay to get a large booster with ingame currency.

Now for gameplay.
The gamplay in Infinity Wars is like gameplay that I have never tryed in a TCG, when building a deck you have three commanders and those commanders limit you to what factions you can use in your deck. Turns are done at the same time with one player having prioraty in a turn for spells and attacks to go first. you also have two ways to lose a game, one being health and other being moral. health is lost by you being attacked directly and moral is lost by losing creatures.

There are 3 battles zones. (Attack, Defence and Support) Attack zone is used to attack your opponents fortress. Defence is used to defend your fortress and the support zone is were most creatures are summoned to. while creatures are in the support zone for the most part they cannot be attacked and they cannot defend. but there are many cards that get around this.

The 7 factions in Infinity wars all have there own style of play. one faction may be a direct assult to the enimy base while another will use more spells then creatures. another relys on its grave to grow in strength.

over all this is a great game I would recommend it to anybody who enjoys MTG. The game also has a great community that will be happy to answer any questions you may ask.

reviewText:
So I have a little bit of a hard time deciding whether or not to recommend this game. On the one hand it has excellent game mechanics and in terms of strategic depth it's probably the best card game I've seen (including magic the gathering - also if you liked magic you will almost certainly love this game!).
That said the game doesn't have the largest player base anymore (only a few hundred people at a time now a days) and there are some noteworthy issues with it.

Rating of IW:

Mechanics: 9.5/10 (and I don't think I'd give anything a 10)

Strategic Depth: 9.5/10

Balance: 6 (it's not horrible and the margin by which it tends to favor certain builds isn't actually that big. But the meta has felt pretty similar for a long time).

Welcoming to new players: Game 1/10; Community 7-8/10. This game takes a lot of time to really get into. It's a great game but expect to put many hours into it to get a feel for the mechanics, tricks, meta, etc. (To give a rough idea I'd say you need to spend about 20hours on this game just to get a decent feel of it).

Developer Responsiveness: 6/10

Bugs: 5/10 (They aren't horrible, you can still play the game and most often don't run into them, but do expect to lose matches occasionally (around 1 in 50?) due to bugs that aren't going away anytime soon).

F2P: 9.5/10

So with regards to the mechanics/strategy. This game uses simultaneous turns and resources automatically increase up to 10. The resources thing is nice (particularly if you are coming from magic, no getting land sc***ed or mana glut) but it's really the simultaneous turns that make this game stand out. Both players que there turns at the same time, on a given turn one player has priority and priority switches player each turn. The order of play is as follows: upkeep and comes into play effects, premeptive abilities, regular abilities, attacking and the other player defending (each of those resolves for the player with priority and then the other player and each player gets to que the order in which their cards happen within those phases) - although it's a lot more streamline when playing it than what I just described sounds.
Since both players turns are qued at the same time and resolve without either player being able to react to them this introduces a lot of bluffing into the game. For example Which zone is this character going to be in? One were they can attack or defend or back in support where they are safer from my opponents removal cards?" A lot of the game has to do with correctly and consistently anticipating your opponents actions and winning a game has as much to do with deck construction as it does with accurately predicting your opponent (depending on the match the second one of these can be more important.. especially in draft formats).

Cards: Cards are quite diverse and comprable to magic the gather in terms of the range of their mechanics. (Noting that magic has something like 20 years on this game
date: so more like magic back in the mercadian masques block).\n\nWelcoming to new players: The community is pretty friendly and will generally be pretty nice to players (well
recommended: maybe not if a player is complaining to them about something that they aren't really the person it should be taken up with
hoursPlayed: but in general). That said the campaign and challenges (a.k.a. tutorial/single player) is pretty short and it takes a very long time to build up ones card pool. So starting out you will probably lose a lot. Try rift runs because at least then the card pool is statistically the same for you and your opponent
voteText: but you won't have the experience with the game that they do and still don't expect to win that much for awhile. Harsh I know

Both of those people are pretty on top of it and I do feel like the developers work pretty hard on the game behind the scenes. Also generally they do actually look at player feedback and address it... eventually. I've made several different suggestions (on rewording particular cards

reviewText:
It's a rather fun card game, but the UI is the real culprit in not recommending this game, specifically the deck building UI.

About the deck building UI concerns:
1.) Until you select the card you don't know what they do, it's no on the card icon. It just shows part of their name (only part of the name) and a big <quanity> number covering 70% of the cards' images. Makes it hard to tell which cards are which.

2.) Sometimes hovering over statuses listed on cards will tell you what they do, other times they won't, it depends on the card, Made learning the game much harder.

3.) This one's more Personal preference, but the cards are listed in a single-file row; I greatly prefer multiple columns of rows so I can see more than 11 cards at a time.

These three things just compacts into an unenjoyable deck building experience for new players like myself, I believe.

reviewText:
First review.

The reason I actually bothered to make a review is because, quite simply, I'm fed up with all the bugs. I've barely gotten any hours in and already had numerous crashes which dropped me from the game or playing the campaign. Obtained items have been missing from the inventory. Buffing a character leads to 'illegal card interaction, game will stop now' non-sense.

Sure, the game is free. And one could argue that you're getting exactly what you're paying for. I dare say however, that if I'm investing my time to be entertained, the very least I'd want to see is a working game.

Their entire business model is based on the premise of keeping you playing and then buying cards to play with. You'd think that they then ensure you atleast can actually play the game.

reviewText:
This game is an unpolished buggy mess.

Mousing over a keyword ability is supposed to explain what the ability actually is, but in almost all cases it just gives you the card's text in another text box.

I've mulliganed and have been unable to drag the only one cost card I have into the play area.

I've leveled up only to not receive any of the rewards I was promised for doing so.

And worst of all are the desyncs that make the game totally unplayable.

On the gameplay side, the non-standard modes appear to be totally barren, those modes being the only ones (other than draft) that eliminate the pay/grind-to-win aspects inherent in any tcg/ccg.

And the draft mode is just a gambling game where you pray to RNGesus to please give you good cards to chose from.

All that being said, it's free to play so I guess there's no good reason for people reading this not to try it.

reviewText:
It's got a lot of good points ... with some work on card dynamics and PVP balancing I'd change my recommendation and overlook the poor splash screens and menus. The semi-scripted AI games and tutorials were VERY enjoyable, having been balanced in designed to provide a reasonable experience. However, PVP play is a different story.

As it is, PVP strategy is mechanically dictated. To win, you must build a deck that exploites -unlimited- (no limit on how many you have) cards enhanced by force multipliers and extermination cards. There are minor variations amongst factions, but they don't alter the basic formula. Once you've got the deck, you just repeat the pattern of play they enable. If the decks are evenly matched winning or losing is mostly a matter of who screws up the formula. Robots will probably enjoy it, I don't.

I'd suggest limiting  the -Unlimited- class of cards (drastically). Force multiplier cards should be limited to one per turn and should affect only a single targeted card. No more every allied card in play gets +3. And no more every enemy card in play dies. These simple changes might add some subtlty to game play and reward strategic thinking rather than encouraging systemized, predictable, turns.

I found the PVP matching system inadequate ... Clicking the -Only match me with other new players- button is a bad joke. I was consistantly matched with advanced players using sophisticated decks.

All in All I think you can find Better CCG games to spend time with.

reviewText:
Infinity Wars is the first Trading Card Game that I've played since Pokemon and Yu-gi-oh when I was a kid.
The campaign is quite long (12 hours more or less) and the Bot games are quite enjoyable.
The matchmaking is decent, games are found within a minute or two, usually, and sometimes in an instant.

Now truth be told I lose most of my PvP games but that's as much due to my skill as due to my decks.
Speaking of cards, they are given out quite generously by completing the campaigns and later on you find something (Card or booster Pack or XP Boost) for going online and again for completing your first three games of the day plus for advancing in levels.
So you'll be able to create your own deck(s) after going through single player and if you keep playing you'll be able to buy Packs with the ingame currency quite frequently.

It's also nice to see that this game is actively being developed.
There's a dev stream as well as weekly challenges and weekly changing free to play decks.
In the end there's quite a lot you can do ingame as there are different factions that you may mix as you please and the games allow for some good strategy but also offer some variety.

If you're into TCGs or strategy games you should give this game a shot.
I find it to be quite relaxing but also quite intense sometimes.
This is as intense as card games get.

Edit:
The campaign was currently remodeled and reduced in size for now. Disregard the supposed twelve hourse to beat.
My Invite Code is 42NTWS if anyone wants to use it when filling out the registration.
The game is already free but with this you'll get an additional pack of cards and so will I.

reviewText:
OVERALL: One of the most engaging and best card games out there. If you're looking for something fresh that is not a yet another reskin of MTG with minor gameplay changes, give this game a shot. It's only 1GB and it's free, you're not losing anything if you don't like it.

Even though the playerbase is pretty small right now, the other players are really newbie friendly and the game itself lets every player access 5 ''competetive'' decks for free each week, meaning that most of the time even if you are matched with a veteran (and you will, trust me) you still stand a chance.

The mechanics are very hard to compare to most online TCGs out there, but they probably come closest to Duels of Champions, with more flexible lanes, the ability to mix factions and, most importantly, simultaneous turns. This means that you not only need to plan your own turn, but also predict what the enemy will do! Once youre both done, all the actions will be played in order, meaning that it's possible to literally dodge out of spells way. There is also a ton of cards available, which is extremely impressive given the fact that they're all nicely animated.

Graphically this game is the best looking one out there, even Hearthstone doesn't come close with it's production values. Each card is animated and while on some it's just a minor detail, some are truly impressive.

There is quite a lot of grind to get cards without paying, but it's possible, especially if you play the draft mode. The developers are working on a solution to it, so you may want to hold on for a bit if that really puts you off.

Downsides? Well, the playerbase is quite small right now, meaning that you'll run into strong players a lot. Personally I like that as it's a proper challenge and I'm still doing just fine, even though I only started this week. Does take a lot of practice and reading though as well as some imagination when you need to guess what they'll do next.

reviewText:
A polished card game that is lacking depth
This is more of an initial review, as i decided to try this game out as it looks great visually.

This is how the game is played:
Each card has a certain amount of points it needs to be played, and each turn you get one more point than the last turn. For most cards you have to wait until your next turn after playing it before you can place them on the battlefield".

So basically... you put down all the cards you can each turn
date: and then put them all in the attack zone
recommended: and then hope your units are stronger than whatever units your oppenent has.\n\nThere is "a little" strategy as you can move your cards around so that someone with a large amount of hitpoints gets attacked first
hoursPlayed:
or perhaps you can sacrifice someone with low hitpoints so that your stronger units take less damage.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So basically.... it's a game of "who has stronger cards wins" and it's very hard to recover if you start to fall behind...

In a way it reminds me of old-yu-gi-oh
voteText: where you place all your cards in attack position and just overpower your opponent. However
helpfulPercent: in YuGiOh you at least have plenty of other cards that can counter this style of play
votesHelpful:
but this game feels a bit mindless.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Things I did like though:
+ Animated Cards are a nice touch and bring cards to life
+ Visually the game looks great in all aspects

Things I did not like:
- Story is awful
votesTotal:
and is very hard to follow what is happening
- Voice Acting
- Not enough depth in the card-game
- Lots of Microtransactions everywhere you look

(I did not play this game very long so take it with a grain of salt)"

reviewText:
TL,DR:
Pros:
+ Free to play (definitely not pay to win, you can get all the cards without spending anything),
+ You get plenty of free cards to start with,
+ Great training and campaign,
+ More complex and interesting that Hearthstone, but less complicated than MTG,
+ Great game balance and plenty of unique factions/play styles,
+ Easy learning curve if you are comming from another TCG
+ Helpful and friendly community in chat,
+ Active Devs! They can even be found in chat,
+ Simultanious turns means little idle time while in a match,
+ It never feels grindy, and if you decide to pay with real money the prices are quite reasonable

Cons:
- Limited playerbase, I have no idea why,
- Game is not without its (minor) bugs,
- While you do get a lot of cards to start with, they are mostly commons and uncommons, you will need to spend a lot of time trying to get rarer cards and cards that you need,
- Card base is nowhere near as large as MTG, but to be expected from a relatively new game.



Long, did Read:
Great for a free to play game. Playing thru the campaign gets you around 600 cards (easily enough to make a decent deck) and enough IP (in game credit) to buy another booster pack. It never feels grindy and it is fun regardless of what cards you own.

After you have completed the training and campaign there is a solid match making system in place for when you want a challenge. On top of that, if you feel that you can't make a competitive deck with your own cards there are weekly free decks to borrow. While the game is definetely a true free to play (you can get all the cards without paying a cent), you will notice the strength of decks of more seasoned players. The main issue isn't the game itself, but the fact that few people have heard about it. Having said that, the AI is puts up decent fight and if you are prepared to wait a lil while to find a match, you are in for a treat!  Alternately invite a friend (it's free) so you don't have to wait to find a match!

Edit: Spelling

reviewText: Pretty great little free to play game.  The campaign mode is fairly extensive, and gives you a pretty nice little starter deck for each faction by the time you finish it. As for the actual gameplay, I certainly enjoy it.  Haven't really gotten deep enough to know if it's 100% balanced, but it's close enough to be a lot of fun

reviewText: I have not played a better digital trading card game, and I have tried quite a few. Infinity Wars seeks to be truly unique by taking full advantage of the digital space, doing things a normal card game cannot easily do. We see basic things like animated cards and persistant health amounts, but we also see the major gameplay element of simultaneous turns, where both players plan out their turns, then once both players hit End, they resolve at the same time. This creates a game where you have to consider what your opponent might be about to do and predict their plans.\n\nAs said, I have never had more fun playing a card game, and I suggest giving it a look.

reviewText:
If you like Trading Card Games you need to look at Infinity Wars. As an avid fan of Star Wars Galaxies TCG, Magic the Gathering Online and Might and Magic Duel of Champions I gotta say Infinity Wras comes in close as my new second favorite on this list.

The most important reasons why I recommend this game in short:
You get a ♥♥♥♥ ton of cards just for playing and fullfilling achievements (called Quests in the game).
You can actually buy booster packs and decks with the ingame currency you get rewarded after each match (never seen that in a TCG before). So you can theoretically completely free load on this game and just play your way to a good deck.
The most rewarding PvP format (Rift Runs) is played using a draft deck the plaer puts together from random cards drawn by the game. Thus it isn't P2W.
Turns are made simultaniously and hidden, which adds a nice layer of bluffing and calling bluffs to the game, which I haven't seen in other TCGs before.
Each faction has it's own specific uses and strategies. Making fun combinations of up to three factions makes for a lot of fun deck possibilities.


Like SWTCG Infinity Wars has etremely nice AI challenges:

You start out with some turorial missions that introduce you to the important gameplay elements of the game.

That is best followed b the academy challenges that introduce you to some advanced strategies and gameplay elements in the form of pretty tough endgames that require you to find the right combination of playing your cards in order to win within or survive that one turn.

Then there are the faction specific campaigns, that give you the back story of each faction, introduce you into it's dominant strategies and reward you with a nice starting stock of cards that belong to that faction.

With those crads you can put together your first own decks and test them against AI opponents in five difficulties.

The only thing missing are 4 player vs. AI missions like SWGTCG did.



The core of the game like in any TCG is PvP play though:

In Normal" mode you can look for games in four different deck formats:
"Core": Only cards from original Infiinty Wars factions can be used (no promo stuff like the Star Trek cards)
"Infinite": Any card can be used in the deck
"Merged": Any card allowed. Before the game starts both player's decks are combined and shuffled together
date:
so both play with the eact same cards.
"Pauper": Only common and uncommon cards.
In "Ranked" matches you play a best of three against another player with a deck.

In "Rift Runs" you put together a deck from random cards presented by the game. The cards are drawn from the collection of all cards that are in the game. Then ou play matches against other Rift Runners until you lost 3 times. The more matches you play the better rewards you get at the end of the run. And on top you can buy the whole deck you used for the run
recommended: the price get's lower the more matches you won on the Rift Run."

The free cards for the day can be both REALLY awesome or a common, but it is one of the few games that stay true to the consistant login yields better rewards." Somedays I will literally login and play three games to get both free cards
date: others i'll get on and just play and get them along the way.\n\nWhile the levels themselves seem to have no purpose
recommended: every time you level up you are rewarded with a free booster pack (untradeable cards however.) In-game currency can be used to buy booster packs that do contain tradeable cards.\n\nPotentially my favorite thing with this game is it's ability to hold true to "No One Deck Wins" (similar to MTG)"

reviewText:
This game looks amazing and has great and inventive mechanics.

I'd recommend it if I could actually play it, but currently the game is as broken as I've ever seen a game be, it's a flip of a coin on whether I'll be able to interact with menus, load into a game with my deck and hand, or even be able to get into the play menu. The game is unplayable without restarting ever few matches, and even when playing it's really clunky. Building a deck is a major pain that takes forever since you have to add cards some cards in an obtuse way to get them into the deck, and if you're unlucky your deck just won't save, or card sprites will stick to the window, or you won't be able to add/remove cards from your deck.

The unranked play is an absolute joke. I played two games, went up against people that either grinded for hundreds of hours to buy the cards they had, or dropped few hundred dollars to make incredibly strong decks. I, on the other hand, had only the cards the game had given me for completing 19 campaign missions, and a deck that was legal and possibly decent if it didn't go up against decks that were stacked with Uniques, epics, and rares. The ranked play is locked behind level 10, which is a bit ridiculous and generally just turns me off of the game entirely.

The campaigns are okay, but generally they just give you a deck and put you up against an AI, tell you very little, then assume that you can use whatever trick or gimmick of your deck to beat your opponnent's deck. It's unintuitive and generally a slog, though some missions are fun, most are very boring or luck based.

The game could be amazing, it really could be; but at the moment it's a broken mess that I will not be revisiting anytime soon. This game is not fit for release, do not pay money into it until you've played at least a few hours and experienced the many bugs and glitches the game has to offer.

reviewText:
This is a great original card game with a complex design. However, despite the complexity it is easy enough to learn and challenging to master.

Pros:

- Range of card packs to choose from

- Amazing animations for each individual card

- Complex and unique structure allowing for a more strategic game

- Easy and vast costomisation

- Story mode with voice acting

- In game chat system

- Nice field animation

- Not overwhelmed by micro transactions

- Similar level match set up

- Well made tutorial

Cons:

- Story is very simple

- Story mode voice acting ranges from amateur to professional making it sound weird at times

- Not a lot of game modes to choose from

- Match making times can be long

- Detailed card animation means less variety of cards. However more is being added.

As you can see, the benifits outweigh the negatives and if you are looking for a beautiful new card came with a wonderful design then this is for you. Addictive, complex and competative!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome card game. I love how it isn't even possibly to play physically due to synchronous turns (as well as the added tactics that that brings) - really makes the game stand out!

It's got ranked constructed play, if you're into that. It's not super hard to get a competitive deck going and you don't need to pay money (though it can help to have some variety) and can earn cards with in-game currency.

Great gameplay, great art, great community - what more do you need?

reviewText:
Despite having played 23 hours I still feel I'm in the early stages of the game, and may change my mind as I understand it better, but for the moment I have to recomend this game.

I played this after feeling burned by Hearthstone so comparison is inevitable. It isn't as polished, I've run into bugs with where text is, the campaign broke and asked me to choose decks instead of using the set one for some missions, some card text is misleading (I've seen one card whose 'in play' actions trigger in the command zone and another that doesn't), but none of it is deal breaking. The animated art is of varying quality and some is rather amauterish. Sounds are good, though not up to the high standard of Hearthstone, there seems to be no voice acting outside of the tutorials.

That seemed fairly negative, but now for the good. The simultanous turns work well, preventing constant pauses to ask whether anyone wants to react without leaving one side completely still. The different zones work well into that and add some interesting chance for outplay. The F2P aspect seems pretty good, giving cards or letting them be bought more easily than Hearthstone though as reward cards are untradable and trading bought (whether with earned ingame or paid for currency) cards adds some hassle, especially for low value cards.

EDIT: After some more time with it, and a bit of money on it I still recomend it despite some of my fears coming true. I feel like I cannot put together a good deck for ranked, but am hopeful that with a bit more time cards I get from daily, weekly, xp and IP earning will fix this. Some cards are bit useless or autoinclude, and looking into the history high level play has been dominated by single decks but there is variety lower than that and it appears to be improving a little. Rift runs, the versions of arenas, don't give very good rewards for decent runs, my first was a 3-3 for which I got back 800 of my 1000 IP enterance fee and an uncommon card- which seems OK except I didn't seem to earn IP at the end of matches so in reality lost at least 600 compared to playing normal games for just one uncommon. You can buy your deck at the end, but without massive wins the cost is very high. Doesn't seem worth it IMO.

reviewText:
I went into this game pretty skeptical, I was still feeling burned by the crap storm that is Magic 2015 and was not feeling very optimistic about finding a good card game. Despite its glaring flaws, Infinity Wars is fun and engaging for those who enjoy Card games.

Pros     Fun and refreshing gameplay mechanics for experienced and/or jaded card game enthusiasts.
Five seperate constructed formats, two of which are aimed at new players with limited card pools.
Has a small and shockingly friendly community of devoted players who are more than willing to help new players.
Decent draft mode
The fully animated cards are beautiful
Kinda free to play
Cons    The price to buy the deck made in a draft is ridiculous (oh, but it's free if you win 30+ times in the draft without losing 3 times! Good luck!)
May be too daunting for players who are unfamiliar with card games.
Still has a few bugs, some of which are extremely frustrating.
Despite an extensive in game tutorial and campaign mode some game concepts are difficult to grasp.
Difficult to earn enough IP" (in-game currency) to get more cards

reviewText:
I've been playing for about a week now.
They've given me so many cards for simply logging in and playing that I actually have a decent spread of decks and playstyles (Unlike MTG Duels. That game is just spam flying to win.)
On Day 5 I got Lightmare Points (Their version of the buyable currency that most Free to Play games have) for simply logging in. Conveniently enough to buy any of the 15-card booster packs, and not actually too far off being able to afford some of the fancier items like full decks and card backs.
Haven't run into any bugs either, despite what other people have said about the game.

Biggest complaint is that, yes, the matchmaking system does seem a tad iffy. One game I'm up against a guy with an overwhelmingly powerful deck, the next I end up fighting somebody using the most basic of Flame Dawn units, so that could do with some work.

Overall though, it's worth a shot if you like card games. Some of the animations (Timely Strike) are hilarious, and all of them are well done.

Extra Edit: I crashed the game by summoning about 50 Inter-Dimensional Phase Bots and many Genesis buffers. Fun!

reviewText:
One of the best TCGs I have ever played. The strategies are diverse and the gameplay rewards players who are good at anticipating their opponents moves. The game is free and rewards you with enough free cards that you can have a great deal of sucsess without putting money into the game. I have been on the top 100 leader board for several months now and have only spent $20 on the game.

The one thing this game is lacking is a large community to support it. My hope is that the sheer quality of the game will attract more players.

For that reason, if you are on the fence about trying this game, I strongly suggest you give it a go. It is a lot of fun.

reviewText: As you can see I have put in a bit of time on this game. It is fun. If you are tired of the simplicity and repetitiveness of meta card games like Hearthstone and MTG, then this might be the breath of fresh air you are looking for. Infinity Wars' mechanics are complex, it will take you a couple hours to get used to how some abilities work, and how the board layout works. The way you play and how you play are unique to IW, and I love it. I've played a lot of hearthstone and I've seen a lot of the same decks OVER AND OVER AND OVER again. This game will not do that, at least not to the extent of other games. Every strong deck archetype has a counter, and each archetype can be played in different ways.\n\nThe mental game is also unlike any other card game. Guessing what your opponent will do with what he has in play is a big part of being good at IW, and I think that is a huge plus and adds a lot to the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is fun and addictive if you are into TCG's like MTG or Hearthstone. Its edge lies in almost endless possibilities of combos reserved on your choice of cards in your deck.

Cons:
-Matchmaking is pretty much who's currently online in the game, since you don't know how many players are in there.
-You end up battling the same player over and over again for about 3-15mins while looking for a normal game or ranked.
-most game modes are there for show
-Prices of decks and booster packs by IP are discouraging to play more.
-Cosmetics are only purchaseable by LP. Only chance to get cosmetics is through pre-order
-A lot of imbalances and glitches (common since it is still in beta)
-Too many cheesers who will end the game in about 8turns as if they are cheating


Pros:
-Solid community, since the devs and mods are practically online everyday to chat. Hence, they can improve the game through direct feedback and players will get their news faster and gain a heads up on what's being added/fixed in the game.
-Wide range of strategy to choose from be it defensive or offensive type of battle as their is a Morale mechanic to the game.
-Great and humorous artwork. Its animation makes it an eye-catcher to new players and veteran players alike as if you want to collect them all.
-There's a rift run mode practically the same with Hearthstone; but it gives you an opputunity to buy the deck (hence getting the cards you need or that might come in handy)

Overall, I recommend this game. If I were to rate it, I guess it's an ok game of 7/10.

reviewText:
This is a game similar to Magic: The Gathering.  It is different from MTG in many ways.  The first is that the turns are taken simultaneously.  You play all the cards you want either from your hand, or move them around the battlefield.  When you have made all the changes you would like to make you hit end turn.  Your opponent has been doing the same thing on his side.  Once both players have hit end turn the turn resolves, with abilities resolving before attacks.

Another difference is the gathering of resources to be able to play cards.  In Infinity Wars it automatically increases each turn, there is no need to play resource generating cards.

Scoring is also different.  In Infinity wars you have what amounts to two different damage counters, one for your fortress and one for morale.  If either one reaches 0 you lose.  If one of your creatures attacks unblocked it will do damage to the fortress.  When a creature is killed its morale value is deducted from its owner's total.

There is an Academy which will teach you how to use the different types of cards, with Basic, Intermediate, and Advanced areas.  When you complete all the sections in an area you are presented with a graduation challenge to help reinforce the subject areas.  There is also a single player campaign that will help you to learn about the different factions.

The game is currently in Early Access Beta, and there are a few glitches.  I have not run into any that make me want to stop playing.  As you play you earn rewards which can be turned into additional cards and booster packs.  You also earn experience points, and along with experience points Infinity Points.  The Infinity Points can be used to buy additional decks, and booster packs.  If you want to get extra cards faster you can purchase them using funds in your Steam Wallet, but anything you can buy without funds by using Infinity Points which you earn by playing.

The game is now out of beta, and in full release.  There have been some balance changes, some good some not, but it is still a great game to play.  There are also new expansion sets which add more cards to the game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOk, after giving the game a real try, i've seen some really cool things that i've liked. First off, I love card games so this game suckered me in when I saw it in the free games tab. One of the coolest features I saw and enjoyed, was the attack and defence zones, it makes way for real strategy, for example if you have a monster with loads of defence but very poor attack, you can put it in your defence zone to soak up damage your enemy is dealing, and vice versa wih cards with good attack but poor defence. This game reminds me of magic, not In a ripoff way, but In a good influnce sort of way. it's good to have a foundation somewere, and face it, even if it's not had any influence from MTG, fanboys are gonna rage hard simply because It's a card game where you attack people. I haven't played the game long enought to report any bugs, but for now, with the interesting tactics thrown in, I'm going to give this beta a 7/10. It's free, so download it, what have you got to lose?

PVP matches are a bit hit and miss with levels not being filtered or taken into account and the Exhiles need more cards to really be a functional standalone deck. I've only ever encountered one bug and it wasnt that big of a deal either. But its beta at the end of the day and i'm LOVING this game.
Great job guys!

reviewText:
Infinity Wars will show you that TCGs were meant to be on a virtual platform.
The artwork of its fully-animated cards is absolutely magnificent and supported by a rich and continuously evolving lore. It will satisfy all hard-core TCG fans with its simultaneous turns and strategic mechanics as well as various ladder and competition systems. As for the newcomers, a well designed training ground is prepared for all the factions of the game and will introduce you to all the basics and lore while rewarding you every step of the way with cards and rewards and with each new coming day just for logging in 
All that being said, its greatest feature is its awesome and welcoming community that you’ll rapidly get to know, especially if you hang around the Live Streams of the game and the entertaining gamers hosting them.
Definitely try out this free-to-play, super fun card game and witness with us the exciting adventure that is the Infinity Wars with its community and the passionate team behind the game, working every day on improving, balancing and growing this game into an institution that will revolutionize its genre.

See you on the battlefield!
