reviewText:
I have to be honest, I was a bit unsure of Infinity Wars at first. This is due to the fact I had been playing a lot of Hearthstone and wanted something different. I had tried other TCGs and CCGs but I could never really get into them. I then came across this game and the fact there was simultaneous turns and deck commanders which peaked my interest. And if I'm honest, I'm happy I downloaded this as it is very good.

I like the simultaneous turns as it adds a little more strategy to the game itself. As you have to try and guess what cards your opponent might play each turn. The turns themselves are timed so you won't feel like you are waiting an age for the next turn to be played.

The battlefield itself is a nice touch as you have 4 zones: Defense, Assualt, Support & Commander (More on that in a little bit). Defense and Assault do what they say, Defense is where you put cards to protect your hit points, Assault is where you put cards to attack your opponent. Support is where most of your cards will be placed when they are played unless they have an ability that lets them be played straight away. As in most cases, you are planning for your next turn and where you want the cards you just played in the Support zone to go. All the zones can be seen by each player so this lets you plan ahead or try and guess where you opponent will play their cards.

The deck commanders is also an interesting idea and for this game, it does work. You can choose to have 3 commanders all from the one faction or a commander from 3 different factions. Keep in mind that this can change how much of a choice you have when creating your own deck. As if you choose to only have 3 commanders from one faction, then you can only choose cards from that faction. Adding a different faction commander lets you use that faction. And they can also be played like normal cards. So if you don't think you have anything in your hand that is suitable, you can play one of them instead. And try and change the outcome a little or a lot.

The commanders themselves are placed in the Command Zone of the battlefield where they lie in wait for you to use them. They can go straight to the Assault of Defense Zone so long as you have enough mana to play them. And they are in full view always so your opponent knows that they are there. During each turn you have to decide where to move your cards, should you keep it in your assault zone and try and take out some more of your enemies health? Or do you think you need to boslter your defenses a little?

You have two sets of hit points as well: Health & Morale. Health is your typical bread and butter health of any TCGs and CCGs. Morale is something a little different. Nearly all cards have Morale"
date: which means when it gets destroyed
recommended: you will lose how much morale that card had. If you run out of Morale
hoursPlayed: then you also lose regardless how much health you had remaining so that is something else you need to keep an eye on whilst dueling.\n\nThis all probably sounds confusing but there is a an option in game to help you practice and learn the rules of the game and even a campaign in which you earns cards for each faction as you progress through it. And you get a free card every day you log into the game. It is only once a day it happens so don't expect it every single time you log in. There are also quests that once completed
voteText: give you cards to add to your ever growing collection. New cards are also released nearly every week and new sets of cards are released every few months. And you can also trade cards with friends. And the developers have said that: "THERE WILL NEVER BE EXCLUSIVE CARDS THAT ONLY A SELECT FEW CAN EARN." As pratically everything in the game can be bought with Infinity Points (IP) which are automatically gained from playing matches and cost no money. In fact most things in the store (aside from cosmetic touches) can be bought with IP. So you never need to buy anything with real money... ever.\n\nNext we come to the animation which I just love. Each card is fully animated and all look amazing. I coud happily spend a lot of time in this game just looking at the cards and most of the time I do. Also included is the option to play weekly free decks given to you so if you are finding it hard to create a deck that helps you win matches
helpfulPercent: try one of the free decks and see if that works for you.\n\nBut before you go headfirst into your 1st PvP match
votesHelpful: I suggest you play the campaign 1st
votesTotal: this will give you an idea what to expect from all the factions in the game and what cards you might find. After that
votesFunny: all I can say is get out there and fight!"

reviewText: IW is one of those CCGs that has a relatively gentle learning curve, while being highly strategic. The lack of P2W is a refreshing change from the ordinary. The booster packs can all be purchased with in-game currency and the level up rewards are extremely generous. Paid options are for non-competitive cards, backgrounds, sceneries and icons.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I rate this game a 10/10. This will probably be the only time i will ever rate a game this high, but right now when you compare this game to ANY CCG/TCG pay or free this out does it every time. So that being said i'm reviewing this game from a card player point of view so lets go

Pros
LOTS of cards and growing
By doing the campaign you should walking away with around 700 cards for all factions.
Each faction feels like own/very different from the others and mixing factions can give cool results
Every turn, you and the other player all do things at the same time, with players switching priorty each turn.
All the cards are animated on top of (foil,platinum and gold cards)
Each day you log in you get a free card of random faction and rareity (no quest or money a day and yes this is good)
And if you feel the decks you have are just took weak, every week there are 5 new decks premade for you to play in most the modes of the game
The devs are pretty cool and interactive with everyone (also very busy always updating and working on the game)
Cons
Player base is not as big as, i myself would like.
If you are used to games like Hearthstone or not used to CCG/TCGS you might have a harder time with the skill curve in here
It does take a little while to be able to buy a single pack with in game currency
the matches take a little longer then a match in Heathstone

Well that is pretty much it for my review. I really with i could of been critical and sound a lot less like a advertisment for the game, but really this game is easily the best out there right now and there is no reason if you like card games to not download this and give it a try. Also for those who might be mad at me for using Heathstone as a comparison a lot, it is the top played card game right now. So that would be this games biggest competition and more people played Hearthstone so they will no more of what i'm talking about in the regard.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I went into this game pretty skeptical, I was still feeling burned by the crap storm that is Magic 2015 and was not feeling very optimistic about finding a good card game. Despite its glaring flaws, Infinity Wars is fun and engaging for those who enjoy Card games.

Pros     Fun and refreshing gameplay mechanics for experienced and/or jaded card game enthusiasts.
Five seperate constructed formats, two of which are aimed at new players with limited card pools.
Has a small and shockingly friendly community of devoted players who are more than willing to help new players.
Decent draft mode
The fully animated cards are beautiful
Kinda free to play
Cons    The price to buy the deck made in a draft is ridiculous (oh, but it's free if you win 30+ times in the draft without losing 3 times! Good luck!)
May be too daunting for players who are unfamiliar with card games.
Still has a few bugs, some of which are extremely frustrating.
Despite an extensive in game tutorial and campaign mode some game concepts are difficult to grasp.
Difficult to earn enough IP" (in-game currency) to get more cards
date: especially for new players who can't win easily.\nSeems to have issues matching players against players with equal skill level
recommended: probably because of the small amount of players\nIf you are looking for a perfect
hoursPlayed: completed card game to play you may need to hold off on playing Infinity Wars. However
voteText: if you can overlook some bugs and a little bit of grinding to get enough cards and skill to keep up
helpfulPercent: it will be a rewarding experience for a card game fan in search of something new."

reviewText:
So, its time to write a first report based on the current state of the game. You should know however I only played a few TCG online and only 2 in RL. Maybe thats helpfull for other ppl without TCG experience.

I want to point out the 3 factors why I love this game so far:
- Interesting mechanics
This game is very different to other TCGs. Its a great advantage, IF you like this. You have to try it out (not only for 3 hours), than you can decide. Imo it has a fresh mechanic that enables various interesting aproaches and mindgames.
Be aware that you have learn" some effects first
date: but they are rly well described ingame
recommended:
also you can see this helptext every time you hover over the cards (also during a game).

Every game you wanna play longer HAS TO HAVE ITS STRENGTH IN THIS AREA!
If the mechanic is to simple
hoursPlayed: you wont play it that long. In this game
voteText:
you discover interesting moves and synergies as you play erverytime.

- Great community
I dont know what decides how a community acts
helpfulPercent: but for this game the community is a big plus. You will need the ppl for two aspects. As there is a complex mechanic
votesHelpful: its always good to get some helpfull tips
votesTotal: new ideas and such. This community will provide it. There are many friendly ppl who help all the newcomers if they have some questions or need some input for their decks.\nSecond
votesFunny: this is a trading game. Ofc not all ppl are the same
commentsCount: but I met so many ppl that not only provided FAIR trades to newcommer
column16: no
column17:
they also made trades in my favor because I still have a rather small collection in comparism to others. This is the second important fact.

- F2P
This is probably the most important information for ALL F2P games. There is and will always be a debatte about the "fairness" of a given game in the F2P aspect.
First
column18: you can start very smooth and will get ALOT cards as a new player FAST. You are also guaranteed to get some better (rarer!) cards during that periode. IF you are lucky
column19: you get ever more rarer cards instead. However
column20: as in every TGC
column21: if you have 100 cards in the end
column22: you will only have a few rares
column23: no matter if they are "rare" "epic" or "legendary" using the ingame-terms.\nSecond
column24: you always get free cards for login
column25: daily wins and quests. Again
column26: some of them are fixed
column27: some of the prices are random (your luck decides!).\n\nThat means
column29: it compares to the fairest F2P games that are currently know. Why is there still a debatte? Because there is the midgame part. Imho this is the part where changes are needed. You have 3 problems after the early period (remember
column30: this starts to happen after 150+ hours
column31: THEN you enter the midgame periode.\n\nFirst
column32: level ups are getting more and more harder (you need more exp for every level) and the highest lvl is currently 50. I am at lvl 27 myself. If you are a more or less casual gamer with only a couple games a day
column33: you will start to feel it. That means the free booster (15 cards) will come on a greater periode.\nSecond
column34: the boosters with ingame money are fair priced
column35: but again as casual it takes some time to get them.\nThird

reviewText:
If you like Magic the Gathering you'll probably like Infinity Wars.
The mechanics are similar in many ways and slightly different in others.
There are 4 zones on the field, the attack, defence, support and command zone while on MTG there's only one zone for everything.
It may seem rather difficult at first, but once you step right into the tutorial you'll understand the concept in a couple of minutes, if you're already used to playing TCG.

reviewText:
So, its time to write a first report based on the current state of the game. You should know however I only played a few TCG online and only 2 in RL. Maybe thats helpfull for other ppl without TCG experience.

I want to point out the 3 factors why I love this game so far:
- Interesting mechanics
This game is very different to other TCGs. Its a great advantage, IF you like this. You have to try it out (not only for 3 hours), than you can decide. Imo it has a fresh mechanic that enables various interesting aproaches and mindgames.
Be aware that you have learn" some effects first
date: but they are rly well described ingame
recommended:
also you can see this helptext every time you hover over the cards (also during a game).

Every game you wanna play longer HAS TO HAVE ITS STRENGTH IN THIS AREA!
If the mechanic is to simple
hoursPlayed: you wont play it that long. In this game
voteText:
you discover interesting moves and synergies as you play erverytime.

- Great community
I dont know what decides how a community acts

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fix Verore Death Worshippers

Imagine this;
-You come up with a brilliant tactic
-Your enemy puts Mass Death into play with atleast three Verore Death Worshippers in support
-All of the perfectly placed offensive and defensive cards are destroyed
-Death Worshippers in support area gain massive amounts of health and damage.
-You instantly lose to a semi invincible horde of 30/30 worshippers
-They have 22 Verore Death Worshippers in their deck so who cares how many die, they have more on backup.

I just think Verore Death Worshippers are extremely broken and need to be fixed, I do not care about Mass Death.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh man, what's with all the great CCGs lately?

The obvious comparison is the other big F2P CCG, Hearthstone And I'd say that this... isn't as good. It lacks Hearthstone's puzzle element and simplicity, there's just not the same feeling of trying to predict and counter the opponent's strategy. The simultaneous turns helps with this a LITTLE bit, but it's just not good enough. Also, cards aren't as easy to come by without trading. And in comparison to Magic The Gathering it just doesn't have quite the same level of depth and option that MTG's massive amount of cards has.

But I'd still put this as miles better than any other TCG! So yeah, I'd really recommend trying it out.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis FTP strategic card game is really addictive.  It has a great campaign mode where you can use premade decks to learn the different factions, all the while unlocking loads of cards to build your own custom decks. If they ever sell physical cards of this game, I would totally buy them.  Loads of deep strategy fun here!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you are into CCG then you should try out Infinity Wars!
I play other CCG like MTG, Soulforge and Herthstone (really???) but this one is growing on my... a LOT!!!
First of all, the overall feeling of the game is very cool... cards, layout, colors...
Then you can win by depleting your opponent life or morale... yap... two way to win!!!! This open up a new way to play a CCG!!!! And the cards... the cards are fantastic! Come on... animated cards... AWESOME!!!!!
And you can earn new cards by playing the game few time a day. So two tumbs up for me!
One last note... the game is free so try it out... you don't have anything to lose.

reviewText:
As you can see, I've played many hours & it's a great game because most of the time a quick games a great game. It doesn't really matter who you vs it's how you play with some already made up decks for newcomers which also changes every now & then which will be an amazing help for them & with some luck you can almost win every match up depending if you understand the mechs.

Whenever I'm in a rush & have 5 - 10 minutes to spare I play this. In my opinion, it's worth the download because there are not that many great card games out there that are quick, fun, slightly addictive making want to jump right into the next match straight away one after the other before realizing an hour has passed.

8/10 Amazing game

regardless this game is so much fun and has such a nice complexity

reviewText: I was very pleasantly surprised by this game! I was expecting something with boring minimal strategy like Hearthstone, but what I got is a system akin to Magic the Gathering; it's just as complex and engaging with a few of its own unique mechanics. I appreciated the tutorial battles, which had minimal hand-holding while still explaining everything very well. The few AI battles I’ve had outside the tutorial so far were challenging enough to be fun, but not so challenging that I felt like the AI was cheating. I look forward to learning more about the system and building my own decks!

reviewText:
Even if you're not a trading card game person like I wasn't, give this a try. I've played this a lot on and off for a couple years since when I've tried other TCGs such as Hearthstone too. And my final conclusion is that Inifity Wars is the best digital card game out there. Here's why:

- F2P model is fine. Free cards every day you log on/Play you first few game/Complete Quests & Acheivements
- Incredible art on the cards
- Brilliant universe for the cards... it's creepy and enthralling with a great take on the undead
- Final Fantasy grade soundtrack
- The deepest strategy out of any TCG I've played by far
- Simultaneous turns (Less waiting around and it allows for more complex strategies)
- Wonderful, imaginative faction/classes which are MIXABLE in each deck you create.
- Massive amount of cards and strategies

The only cons that I can see really are:

- Why isn't this game getting more attention?
- Although the game itself is very tight, the program and gui itself could use a little work.
- The menu system could be better, smoother and streamlined etc.

reviewText:
Infinity Wars tries a lot of bold new things. Some of these succeed, while others do not.

Firstly, and unfortunately most importantly, the game is genuinely free to play. It isn't Heartstone free to play, where non-paying players need to grind for years to accumulate the same quality of cards as someone who spends $1000. IW lives up to its name. A new player has the potential to build a competitive deck from just the cards he receives from the tutorial, and initial booster packs ('soulbound packs'). Those who choose to spend are able to gain platinum cards (just shiny), better artwork, sounds, effects, etc, and more cards to play with, BUT THESE CARDS ARE NOT NECESSARILY ANY BETTER. They are just more options to explore should you get bored of using the same, but highly effective, strategy every game. No cards are locked behind a pay-wall, although if you want to build a deck with 10+ legendaries in it (that is NOT NECESSARILY BETTER THAN A DECK WITH 0 LEGENDARIES), be prepared to pay or grind.

There isn't much to say about the artworks or effects. If you like them, great. If not, you don't. There's no option to turn them off, but then again, we aren't playing Microsoft Excel.

The community is also extremely active, for its size. It is certainly no Heartstone, which has the publishing collosus of Blizzard behind it, nor is it Yugioh, where even in my relatively small town there are frequently 20-30 player tournaments with prizes. The developers, too, are frequently active on the forums, and this game has been patched at once a month since I began to play. I say this with absolute confidence; if this game has a larger player base, it has the potential to lead the market with its innovation and new ideas.

Why, then, do I NOT recommend this game for you?

It's free, so there's no harm trying. But as you progress beyond Puffy the Fish and encounter more and more cards and combinations, you will realise one serious flaw in the game design. The devs have shown they are not a money laundering scheme, and genuinely wish to see this game develop into something for the gamers to enjoy. They design and maintain their game with all the best intentions, but unfortunately in this case it does not equate to results.

Infinity Wars has a unique turn system unlike Heartstone, MTG, Yugioh, etc. I remember something similar in some Marvel DC comic card game ages ago, and that is that both players have their turns at the same time. Not only is this extremely confusing for new players (this, and the copious amount of addon-systems that are needed as a result, to determine things like card resolution order, etc), it is also fundamentally incompatible with their card design, which follows a far more traditional MTG/Yugioh approach.

In short,  the cards for this game do not match the rules for this game. It is like eating Butter Chicken Flavoured Ice Cream, driving to work in a $2999 bottle of wine eating your favourite hamburger while diving into a beautiful coral reef. Oil and water don't mix. Or, for a more contextual example, like throwing a pokemon card into Yugioh. What are energies??? At best, this system leads to frustrating gameplay, where both players are reluctant to do anything out of fear, that they will incorrectly anticipate between two WHOLLY VALID courses of play and thus screw themselves over for the rest of the game. At worst, this creates massive imbalances in the game due to some cards being overpowered in the context in which they are placed. For example, 'draw 3 cards' is a common effect in pokemon. Put that card into yugioh, and it will completely break the game.

The game has a great community, great ambitions and has the potential to change the face of TCG games. However, this is no easy task, and despite the best intentions of the DEVS, clearly indicated by the fact that the game is not pay to win, the gaping flaws in the game's current fundamental design will not allow it to provide a largely positive experience.

reviewText:
I think people are very upset because they don't accept losing. They can't fathom the fact that they spent hours, if not days, planning their starter decks with a few boosters for the perfect play and still lose. (Read the most helpful review, the dude lost because his opponent outplayed him so he posted a Negative review lmao!)

I've not once ever seen a paper TCG/CCG that you can't get s**t on for playing basic, common, starter-deck, builds. All the way from Magic to Yugioh to Pokemon. If you didn't expand your deck and you build strategies, people will take advantage of that and beat you. Starter decks are literally what they say, it's just that start. They aren't meant to be the most optimal decks straight from that bat that beats everything else with a few clever moves.

Building successful paper decks have always taken a great amount of time, energy, and sometimes even money. People love to be hand-held through every game now a days. They rely on streamers and youtube to actually enjoy a game, but they have no idea how much fun everything was when none of that stuff existed and you had to travel out of your computer seat and search for those NEW cards. Sometimes even get in your car and drive for an hour to a tournament to see those cards you've never heard of before because your friends or yourself have never picked them up from boosters. It was all part of the adventure and charm of these games.

I truly do enjoy the game even when I get my butt handed to me because it's a learning experience. Each time I lose to an opponent, I learn how to counter them a little bit better. I learn the pacing and when I finally do get those cards I want/need, I will have everything in my wits to beat them and man is it rewarding as heck when you do.

reviewText:
Here is everything you need to know about this games free to play currency.

If you play through the entire 7 tutorial levels, and then entire 10 other tutorial levels it refuses to also call tutorial levels, and the 64 campaign levels,.. and that was apparently 11 hous of  hours of play according to steam...

... you do not have enough free currency to buy even one single standard sized 15 card booster pack.

NOT.

EVEN.

ONE.

Yeah sure you get cards for the campaign and levelling up". That you can't trade. But walking out of the 11 hours of introductory campaign without enough currency for even one standard sized booster?

Stingy. Very Stingy."

reviewText:
Final Review 9/5/2014

Honestly, I'd like to say that I had a whole bunch of information to drop upon IW's release, but I don't. Release for this game was not so much a bang but a very timid whimper. My honest opinion is that it felt rushed if solid, giving it a very mediocre launch.

There are no big changes so I can't find my revised review changing all that much. Several much-needed card fixes were implemented, but that's not what should set a gold release apart. The truth is there's no point in adopting this game at all as it sits, if you played beta you're not missing anything. If you have to pick up this game might as well wait for 2015. That's when most of the launch features a TCG should have wil be implemented.

The game is barebones at the moment. It didn't launch with any kind of card recycler or revamped rewards system. The developers think that's fine, I find it a grind. Even something as basic as a tournement mode didn't make it into release. The truth is they're still on a player-to-player system and, you guessed it, serverside matchmaking won't be making it until the year after release, and dysincronizations and endless turns are still very much a reality. Current plans for IW 2015 make this feel like Beta Mk 2 not Ver 1.0.

I'm out of room. Can't recommend.

Revised Review 5/5/2014
----
So, I decided to give the game a more in-depth review at the behest of some of the developers. My main review is mostly still intact, so I'll detail where it changes and my new experiences with a month worth of play. Despite what Steam says it's over 40 hours (I dont' play with Steam in online mode a lot).

Like I said before the game has potential that's almost all it's working on. I saw that patch .96 was live so if convention is to be believed it's very close to release, so I don't buy that, It's beta" excuse everyone from the developers to the community likes to foist on you. It's way too close to a 1.0 version for that to be a sufficient. Still
date:
if you're a person who like to play games based on the promise of what they might be (a la Dwarf Fortress or something). I'm not really going to convince you. I'm here to report on what exists. I can't critique things that don't exist.

The AI is horrible (They've "got plans"). I beat the most difficult AI routinely and draw it out if I'm lazy. I think I lost once to it because I wasn't paying attention. You can beat the AI with just about any deck you can put together. The campaign serves as less of a story and more as an extended tutorial to get you cards.

The bugs and glitches are still pretty bad. At .96 you'd expect most of the core modes to be at least pretty solid
recommended: but Rift Run (there version of draft) didn't work right for about two weeks I was there. Every patch seemed to make the game worse. While they'd fix some things they'd introduce two issues for every issue they fixed. Some people tell me that's "how development goes" but I'll let you realize who paradoxical that is.\n\nSpeaking more on the modes. Rift Run (again their Draft) is actually an exercise in how much money you're willing to pour into it (thankfully not real world money). At one-thousand Infinity Points (the free currency) it's actully quite cheap to at least make sure you have ideal commanders
hoursPlayed: cheapinging the spirit of the mode.\n\nThe factions: The game is pretty strong
voteText: it still feels really random to me
helpfulPercent: but you learn a few tricks. It still does feel like you're throwing cards. One faction (their first post-core faction) is basically unplayable by itself and is generally in need of reowrking. It's been through one already. That gives me pause to invest in the next non-core release
votesHelpful: Ascenscion.\n\nThe only way to get free card packs after a while becomes leveling up. Which is fair. They don't have to give you free packs for everything. You get a few single cards for weekly quests and the fee card for your daily login and first three games of the day
votesTotal: which makes sure you get a card for participating
votesFunny: but the leveling up is purely geometric in scale (one more thousand exp to level up) in scale. You get one pack no matter how much it actually took to get to the next level. So the rewards remain the same while you're doing more work for the same thing. That naturally make leveling up a grind. If you're the kind of person who can do PVP all day long with no change then more power to you.\n\nIf found the community by in large hostile if you didn't toe the general opinion. Any critique of the game is met with "It's in beta' again remember they're at version .96
commentsCount: that's almost release
column16: or it's met without outright nastiness
column17: which I suppose is just the nature of the beast when you're dealing with anything over the internet. The inablity to take and evaluate criticism is only going to hurt the game in  the long run. They'll probably say bad things about me
column18:
but I don't really care.

There are a few other small issues that give me pause to invest anymore time into the game. A sale was held on a deck recently. The sale was in LP (Lightmare Points the real-money currency) and not Infinity Points. I asked around and that wasn't something done before with both currencies being slashed for the sale. That smacks of riding the P2W line. So be careful if you do decide to adopt this game.

All in all

----
While this game has a lot of potential it falls down in a few key areas one would expect a trading-card game to flourish in. Turn length is painfully long and busy
column26: and their are far too many mechanics to keep in mind as you play. Including what order your creature cards are in and where they are on the zone.\n\nWhile the simultaneous turn mechanic might seem like it speeds up gameplay the uneeded general complexity of the game at large keeps it from being effective. Also
column27:
the simultaneous turn resolution (though there is initiative to keep in mind as well) gives the game a painfully random element beyond simple luck of the draw. It felt more like I was throwing cards at a brick wall and seeing wich ones took rather than leading an army in a grand strategic victory. Instead of skillful counters and repostes it feels more like you're constantly punching in the dark at one another.

In this regard the mechanics of the game shine a light on a dominant strategy that shouldn't be so dominantly effective in this genre as to be the go-to strategy: The rush. Rush decks are the majoiry and the game tends to punish slightly slower than rush decks. It makes the game feel stale and samey.

That being said collecting cards is fun
column28: and the game does offer up many rewards. If you can get past the cumbersome mechanics progress feels nice. The cards are animated with looping gif-like pictures on each and every card which is pretty
column29: but also fees gimicky. Battles aren't fought in any cenematic way. Cards bump into each other doing their damage. The factions are fairly distinct and the art is nice with shades of Warhammer 40K in a blend of sci-fi-coated fantasy.\n\nThe game is in beta now
column30: but as a representation of what we can expect it leaves a lot to be desired. The lovely if pointless card animations and promise of what are supposed to represent battlefield style engagements are marred by stilted and random mechanics. reviewText: tl;dr: I like it a lot.\n\nI've never really been able to get into the CCG/TCG scene due to the fact that I'm always poor. Recently I started playing Hearthstone which I love but it doesn't have TONS of depth or strategy. Then, I remembered reading about Infinity Wars so I hopped on Steam to check it out. I love it! With the multiple zones, multiple factions and being able to win by dropping either the health or morale of your opponent, the amount of strategy in this game is ridiculous! Though, the amount of options does add a bit of a learning curve, the tutorials and Campaign are a great way to learn the game before jumping into PvP. Added to the fact that you get a decent amount of cards from the campaign and leveling up you don't actually have to drop any money to enjoy it! I might end up spending some real money down the road but as of now I don't think this is as Pay 2 Win as other F2P CCG's. Add the fact that you can trade (unsoulbound) cards with your friends and you have the formula for an awesome as hell Free 2 Play TCG! Download. Play. Enjoy!

reviewText:
Will keep the review basic and since it's F2P, you can give it a go yourself to check whether the game suits you. This game is not very well balanced, more a Pay To Win, and I have played other games, like Magic The Gathering and Might & Magic: Duel of the Champions and there new player actually has some chances to win in PvP. This coupled with slow game look up process makes me want to switch to other games rather than spending time waiting for game to start only to get some experienced PVP opponent with deck that kills me in sometimes even less than game start waiting time (not sure if the player base is so small or whatelse..)

Pros:
- Nice graphic
- Animated cards
- Variety of cards and sides you can take on (each having it's own weaknesses and advantages)
- Many campaigns (and you can get some free decks by doing them)
- In-game challenges & achievements (who doesn't like them)
- Background story
- Rift Run - seems to be interesting concept. Played only once, but that seemed to be giving some chances to new players (considering you can pay the entry fee that is). It does make you draft your deck from random cards, so you don't have to have them yourself.

Cons:
- Slow PVP matchmaking - on average it takes couple of minutes to find a game. Not once, I was able to get myself some coffee or even eat something while waiting for game to start and when returning, it was still trying to lookup.
- Bad matchmaking - in 9 out of 10 cases I have been playing opponents with lots of gold or higher medals on profile, meaning they did spend a looot of time in PVP (and the game) polishing their decks and getting lots of cards
- Pay to win - some say you can get cards - sure, you can get. It's a slow process though and you have to play really a lot of games to get some. Mainly you get them by playing campaigns, and that's the easy part, but you don't get anything too fancy. Sure, you get also in-game money, but it trickles like from closed but leaking tap and again, play A LOT and you can eventually get few cards - still though, if you want to go PVP, you better consider spending some money to get better cards.
- Still has bugs - didn't see anything major, more like a cosmetic and graphical mainly on claiming rewards where you may need to claim same twice or the interfaces are overlapping (reward claim interface with others)


All in all, over Infinity Wars I would much more prefer for example Duel of Champions where matchmaking is way better and some seasonal player can actually get chances to win without spending real world money and get some fun rather than just waiting to be pwned.
If you're only going to play Infinity Wars occassionally, then rather look for an alternative.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's no Magic: The Gathering, but Infinity Wars is a solid, free-to-play digital TCG. Being digital does allow Infinity Wars to do some pretty cool things that aren't possible with physical TCG's - like simultaneous turns and actively creating cards during gameplay. The simultaneous turn system adds an interesting, poker-esqe level of strategy. It allows you to guess, or force, your opponent's moves rather than simply react to them. There are several factions from which to build decks, but each faction seems so lazer-focused on a single mechanic that there is little room for building a unique" deck. This will probably improve as cards are added over time
date: and it doesn't keep the game from being fun in the meantime."

reviewText: One of the best out there with nearly unlimited deck building options, and most importantly a good player base that never takes more than a few seconds to grab a live match. AI is pretty good for Easy mode even if its kinda derpy at times. Can't wait to see the harder modes unlocked. Already some skill out there too, good players and new alike, matchmaking seems to be good too. Campaigns and leveling gives all kinds of booster packs as you progress so free to play is certainly true. Though (as with most all tcg) you can pay your way to a better deck it really doesn't do more than give you a head start as all cards are freely obtainable (all level reward packs are random boosters), and having a bunch of good cards will never guarantee victory with this game. True TCG where tactics reign. Good luck to any wanting to try it out, don't wait its definitely worth it.

reviewText:
Time ago I was about to try the game, then I read the various negative reviews and disinstalled it before trying because they claimed it was a PTW and unplayable for new players, so I tried other tcg. I was an avid Hearthstone player and tried Hex and Magic. Well, after a while I tried anyway IW because I wanted to give it a try. Well, it was a blast.

NOTHING of what those reviews said was true after trying the game. I don't know if they changed something, but it's just a week I play and I have 400+ cards just by playing the campaign and logging in.

I receive free cards every day for logging and another for playing 3 games in any mode.

Plus I can even sometime win against ranked veterans with just a week of playing under my hood. Granted there are great decks and players out there that can blast me away, but is more a matter of experience and missing maybe some card here and there.

Plus there is the fact you can even play legendary free decks that they put up every week on rotation, and even if you don't have enough cards those decks are good and also train you to new strategies and combos and explain you new cards.

So, don't let those old negative reviews discourage you, the game is completely playable FOR FREE, and you can become pretty competitive given a bit of time (not too much too!).
The game is fun also, very interesting factions and strategies, different ways to win, a lot of sinergies and different decks variants.

I played Hearthstone, Hex, magic and none stands up to IW.

Try it for a week, then decide!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First I'll start with the good qualities of the game.

It's a fairly easy game to pick up and very easy to construct a deck to play with. 40 cards is the minimum.
You get to choose 3 commanders - these are creature cards that start in a special section of the board called commanders and their abilites can be used at the offset but if you want them in battle you still have to pay the cast cost to get them out.

It's fairly easy to get booster packs without actually having to pay anything. All you have to do is complete achievements and earn the ingame currency. Since you earn every time you win a battle (you earn in PVP even if you lose) it is easy to just keep buying boosters until you get the cards you want.

The bad side?

There are some bugs that prevent a game from completing (rarely).
The matchmaking can be a little daunting but I think this may be because of the lack of players.

All up, a great card game that is an enjoyable alternative to MTG with some surprises.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Infinity Wars (IW) - is a great dCCG!

I found it quite innovative in comparison to more traditional collectiable card games (such as Magic The Gathering, HEX, Shadow Era and others). In addition to different strategies thinking it also makes you think of bluffing and assuming your opponents moves in planning phase as a turn actions then resolve simultaneously. It's easier to see how it plays or try it by yourself then to describe it!

A great art, animated cards makes this game highly enjoyable!

Also a lot of game modes available: Academy (which learns you the basics and more advanced rules of the game), campaign (8 missions per each faction) rewarding you with starter decks and even more cards, AI battles and different PVP modes, quest system also rewards you for your in game progress!

Though IW still in beta, the game is still under constant development and sometimes some bugs could occur and some issues in the game could be noticed (For me the UI should be more user friendly for example). But I am sure it will become better and better.

Really waiting this game to be released for mobile devices (iOS, Android) so could play it when not at home.

As a conclusion, this title has a great potential and I could recommend it for every TCG player.
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you're into ATCG's, then you'll love Infinity Wars! It has a a small learning curve which is great for newcomers,  and overall is very balanced! The game is still in beta, and therefore has slight matchmaking issues and other network bugs, but it still makes for a great game. The tutorial is very short and fluid, so you'll be diving into the core game very quickly. Also, once you start leveling and opening booster packs, you won't be able to stop! Also- Microtransactions. Yes, they are present, but they aren't even close to the gamebreaking micro transactions that EA and King put out. They merely offer cosmetic changes, as well as a faster way to purchase more booster packs/decks (which are already available through the game's in-game cash). Infinity Wars will also have a mobile game dropping later this year for Android and iOS devices, be it a phone OR a tablet! With the few minor matchmaking glitches and bugs, this game still deserves an easy 8/10!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPutting a fresh spin on card games in a digital format is difficult.  Getting beyond the set standards and being successful in a genre that has been dominated by a single entity for years even more so.  But what Infinity Wars does great isn't beating anyone, but offering a new, fresh perspective in a universe filled with enough lore to write a full book series.  The stories of the factions are rich, they each have their own unique play style, and game mechanics offer a new look at card game strategy that you wouldn't see anywhere else.  This may just be a beta, but I constantly find myself saying One more game" far beyond the point that I should have gone to bed.  A truly amazing experience
date: and definitely a highly recommended one."

reviewText:
Feel like Hearthstone is getting tedious to play?
Want to play a great card game online that you don't have to put money into like MTGO?

Well, if you answered yes to any of those question then you should definitely try this game out. If you answered no you should most likely still try this game out.

Infinity Wars is a great card game that offers a lot of strategic play and interesting card/faction combinations.
There are 8 different factions + factionless in the game and they all have their individual type of feel and playstyle which makes sure that there's something for everyone.
The zone system and the simultaneous turns really gives the game another layer of depth since you have to read your opponents and adjust your plays to suit the current situation.

I've played a lot of card games in my life and I feel like Infinity Wars is a fresh breeze to the genre. If you feel like trying out a card game, don't overlook Infinity Wars.

reviewText:
As the first TCG I have ever played I must say I'm hooked. Being the turns simultaneous, you are forced to anticipate your opponents movements, similar to Frozen synapse. Once you finish the campaign you will have enough cards to start building your own deck and within few games you will realize this game is not P2W at all. Using a modified rush-oriented deck (no legendaries) with a lot of work on the balance, I have been able to hold my ground against a lot of experimented players.
You can play the game without spending a cent and still get the card you want by trading/rewards/booster packs.

The art on the cards is not polished as in other games, but the mechanics are attractive enough to keep you playing.

reviewText:
Wow, what can I even say about this game.  So I'll just start from here:  the game is FANTASTIC!  I'd never heard about this until it popped up in my 'reccomended for you' section, and I am super glad I downloaded it.

Infinity Wars is a digital TCG where every card is animated and have many cool mechanics.  The mechanics involve similar tropes to what you've seen in other TCG's, but what sets IW apart is it's gameplay where players take their turns simultaneously and then have the turns resolved to see who was able to 'predict' their opponents mathups better.  It's difficult to explain without actually playing the game, and you will probably be destroyed several times before you even feel like you're making progress.  But when you do manage to beat somebody, oh boy does it feel good.  The sense of accomplishment is huge and makes me want to keep playing forever.  With several modes of cinstructed to the Hearthstone-Arena-type draft, there is something for everbody.

Now, there are a few drawbacks to the game, but the devs appear to be doing a good job of getting things ironed out and making the experience better and better.  You will occasionally have a few graphical glitches when trying to view cards, like words from the previous screen you were on popping through, and a couple small minor things, but those are not very major and can be easily looked past IMO.  The biggest drawback you may find is the amount of people that play the game is fairly small, so it can be difficult for new players like myself to get involved in the game because we get destroyed by those who are better than us.

Overall, this game was a hugely pleasant surprise for me, I'm gald I decided to play it.  I can truly say that it puts Hearthstone to shame

reviewText: This is an excellent trading card game.  The free-to-play works well; I've been tempted to buy cards, but I can play Draft as much as I like without spending money, and there are other modes (Merged and Pauper) that exist to help newbies be competitive without having great cards.  I win reasonably often in the unrestricted mode, especially now that I've completed the (rather enjoyable) single-player campaign.\n\nIf you've ever enjoyed a trading card game, you should try Infinity Wars.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game is very fun and you dont feel like your getting cards without endlessly grinding for booster packs. The different factions are quite different and fun. But this game has HORIBBLE BALANCE none of the factions themselves are op but there is a handfull of cards that are ridiculously overpowered and the main reason for this is because this game lacks removal for continuous spells,locations and units in the support or command zone. It is very stressfull when there is a building that allows me to only attack with one unit per turn while they use a card that spawns one unit in ther defence zone each turn and there is NO cards for either of the factions in my deck that can remove it. Il reccomend this game but be warned that the balance is a nightmare. Hopefully this is because its in beta still.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, pretty easy everything.

-Huge problem: The multiplayer doesn't seem to have a level filter, so you will face people that have complete decks while you may have only a few good cards. The decks are set up to easily counter each other, too. Warpath and Green Dragon beat Flame Dawn, Sleepers and Venore beat Genesis, Flame Dawn and Warpath beat Exiled, Sleepers and Genesis beat Warpath. The list goes on. So if you meet a player that has a deck that counters yours, good luck.

-Negatives aside, the game is pretty okay. Pretty basic. You gain resources each turn to play creatures and abilities to overcome the opponent. Nothing extremely spectacular, so far, besides the idea of animated cards. The campaign is pretty easy until the last battle of each faction.

-The game itself isn't really Pay-to-Win, it's more of Pay-to-get-a-head-start. Any card you buy with real money can be earned either through login rewards, or battle points.
